24090_13_ITEM1A_P81_S0	Insurance company regulation is generally designed to protect the interests of policyholders, with substantially lesser protections to shareholders of the regulated insurance companies.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P81_S1	To that end, all the states in which we do business have insurance regulatory agencies with broad powers under law with respect to such things as: licensing companies to transact business; mandating capital and surplus requirements; regulating trade and claims practices; approving policy forms; and restricting companies' ability to enter and exit markets.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P82_S0	The capacity for an insurance company's growth in premiums is partially a function of its required statutory surplus.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P82_S1	Maintaining appropriate levels of statutory surplus, as measured by statutory accounting practices prescribed or permitted by a company's state of domicile, is considered important by all state insurance regulatory authorities.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P82_S2	Failure to maintain required levels of statutory surplus could result in increased regulatory scrutiny and enforcement action by regulatory authorities.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P83_S0	Most insurance regulatory authorities have broad discretion to grant, renew, suspend and revoke licenses and approvals, and could preclude or temporarily suspend us from carrying on some or all of our activities, including acquisitions of other insurance companies, require us to add capital to our insurance company subsidiaries, or fine us.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P83_S1	If we are unable to maintain all required licenses and approvals, or if our insurance business is determined not to comply fully with the wide variety of applicable laws and regulations and their interpretations, including the USA Patriot Act, our revenues, results of operations and financial condition could be materially adversely affected.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P84_S0	Although the U.S. federal government has not historically regulated the insurance business, the Dodd-Frank Act, enacted in July 2010, expands the federal presence in insurance oversight.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P84_S1	The Act's requirements include streamlining the state-based regulation of reinsurance and non-admitted insurance (also known as surplus lines insurance, which is property or casualty insurance written by a company that is not licensed to sell policies of insurance in a given state).
24090_13_ITEM1A_P84_S2	This legislation also establishes a new Federal Insurance Office within the U.S. Department of the Treasury with powers over all lines of insurance except health insurance, certain long-term care insurance and crop insurance.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P84_S3	The Federal Insurance Office is authorized to, among other things, gather data and information to monitor aspects of the insurance industry, identify issues in the regulation of insurers about insurance matters and preempt state insurance measures under certain circumstances.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P84_S4	As this Act calls for numerous studies and contemplates further regulation, the future impact of the Act on our results of operations or our financial condition cannot be determined at this time, but could have an adverse impact on profitable operations.

24090_13_ITEM1A_P125_S0	our board of directors may issue one or more series of preferred stock without the approval of our shareholders.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P126_S0	State insurance laws generally require prior approval of a change in control of an insurance company.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P126_S1	Generally, such laws provide that control over an insurer is presumed to exist if any person, directly or indirectly, owns, controls, holds with the power to vote, or holds proxies representing 10% or more of the voting securities of the insurer.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P127_S0	In considering an application to acquire control of an insurer, an insurance commissioner generally will consider such factors as the experience, competence and financial strength of the proposed acquirer, the integrity of the proposed acquirer's board of directors and executive officers, the proposed acquirer's plans for the management and operation of the insurer, and any anti-competitive results that may arise from the acquisition.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P127_S1	In addition, a person seeking to acquire control of an insurance company is required in some states to make filings prior to completing an acquisition if the acquirer and the target insurance company and their affiliates have sufficiently large market shares in particular lines of insurance in those states.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P127_S2	These state insurance requirements may delay, deter or prevent our ability to complete an acquisition.

24090_13_ITEM1A_P129_S0	We have never paid cash dividends on our Class A common stock, as it is our policy to retain earnings for use in the operation and expansion of our business.
24090_13_ITEM1A_P129_S1	We do not expect to pay cash dividends on our Class A common stock for the foreseeable future.

24090_13_ITEM3_P0_S0	We are a defendant in a lawsuit filed on August 6, 1999, in the Texas District Court, Austin, Texas, now styled Delia Bolanos Andrade, et al., Plaintiffs, v. Citizens Insurance Company of America, et al., Defendants in which a class was originally certified by the trial court and reversed by the Texas Supreme Court in 2007 with an order to the trial court to conduct further proceedings consistent with its ruling.
24090_13_ITEM3_P0_S1	The underlying lawsuit alleged that certain life insurance policies CICA made available to non-U.S. residents, when combined with a policy feature that allowed certain cash benefits to be assigned to two non-U.S. trusts for the purpose of accumulating ownership of our Class A common stock, along with allowing the policyholders to make additional contributions to the trusts, were actually offers and sales of securities that occurred in Texas by unregistered dealers in violation of the Texas securities laws.
24090_13_ITEM3_P0_S2	The remedy sought was rescission and return of the insurance premium payments.
24090_13_ITEM3_P0_S3	On December 9, 2009, the trial court denied the recertification of the class after conducting additional proceedings in accordance with the Texas Supreme Court's ruling.
24090_13_ITEM3_P0_S4	The remaining plaintiffs must now proceed individually, and not as a class, if they intend to pursue their claims against us.
24090_13_ITEM3_P0_S5	Since the December 9, 2009 trial court ruling, no individual cases have been further pursued by the plaintiffs.
24090_13_ITEM3_P0_S6	The probability of the plaintiffs further pursuing their cases individually is unknown.
24090_13_ITEM3_P0_S7	An estimate of any possible loss or range of losses cannot be made at this time in regard to individuals pursuing claims.
24090_13_ITEM3_P0_S8	However, should the plaintiffs further pursue their claims individually, we intend to vigorously defend any proceedings.
24090_13_ITEM3_P1_S0	SPFIC is vigorously defending a lawsuit filed in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina and currently pending in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.
24090_13_ITEM3_P1_S1	This matter was filed by the Louisiana Attorney General against SPFIC and every other homeowner insurer doing business in the State of Louisiana, on behalf of the State of Louisiana, as assignee, and on behalf of certain Road Home fund recipients.
24090_13_ITEM3_P1_S2	Although this lawsuit was originally filed as a class action, the Louisiana Attorney General moved to dismiss the class in 2011 and the motion was granted.
24090_13_ITEM3_P1_S3	In this matter the State alleged that the insurers failed to pay all damages owed under their policies.
24090_13_ITEM3_P1_S4	The claims currently pending in this matter are for breach of contract and for declaratory relief on the alleged underpayment of claims by the insurers.
24090_13_ITEM3_P1_S5	All other claims, including extra-contractual claims, have been dismissed.
24090_13_ITEM3_P2_S0	The District Court has issued a case management order requiring the State to produce specific detail by property supporting its breach of contract allegations.
24090_13_ITEM3_P2_S1	Additionally, the case management order requires the State to deliver a settlement proposal to SPFIC and the other defendant insurance companies.
24090_13_ITEM3_P2_S2	Since, there are many potential individual claims at issue in this matter, each will require individual analysis and a number of which may be subject to individual defenses, including release, accord and satisfaction, prescription, waiver, and estoppel.
24090_13_ITEM3_P2_S3	There has been no discovery in connection with this matter.
24090_13_ITEM3_P3_S0	SPFIC believes its claims practices in connection with Katrina homeowners claims were sound and in accordance with industry standards and state law.
24090_13_ITEM3_P3_S1	There remain significant questions of Louisiana law that have yet to be decided.
24090_13_ITEM3_P3_S2	SPFIC intends to vigorously defend all claims asserted in any remaining proceedings.
24090_13_ITEM3_P3_S3	Therefore, in SPFIC's judgment given the issues discussed above, an estimate of probable loss cannot be made at this time.
24090_13_ITEM3_P4_S0	SPFIC is vigorously defending a number of matters in various stages of development filed in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina and Hurricane Rita in addition to the Road Home Litigation, including a number of individual lawsuits, which are immaterial to the Company's financial statements.

24090_13_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following is management's discussion and analysis of the consolidated financial condition and consolidated results of operations of the Company.
24090_13_ITEM7_P0_S1	It is intended to be a discussion of certain key financial information regarding the Company and should be read in conjunction with the Consolidated Financial Statements and related Notes to this report on Form 10-K.
24090_13_ITEM7_P1_S0	We conduct operations as an insurance holding company emphasizing ordinary life insurance products in niche markets where we believe we can achieve competitive advantages.
24090_13_ITEM7_P1_S1	As an insurance provider, we collect premiums on an ongoing basis to pay future benefits to our policy and contract holders.
24090_13_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company derives its revenues principally from 1) premiums earned for insurance coverages provided to insureds; 2) net investment income; and 3) net realized capital gains and losses.
24090_13_ITEM7_P3_S0	Profitability of our insurance operations depends heavily upon the Company s underwriting discipline, as we seek to manage exposure to loss through favorable risk selection and diversification, management of claims, use of reinsurance, the size of our in force block, actual mortality and morbidity experience, and our ability to manage our expense ratio, which we accomplish through economies of scale and management of acquisition costs and other underwriting expenses.
24090_13_ITEM7_P4_S0	Pricing adequacy depends on a number of factors, including the ability to obtain regulatory approval for rate changes, proper evaluation of underwriting risks, the ability to project future losses based on historical loss experience adjusted for known trends, the Company s response to competitors, and expectations about regulatory and legal developments and expense levels.
24090_13_ITEM7_P5_S0	The Company seeks to price our insurance policies such that insurance premiums and future net investment income earned on premiums received will cover underwriting expenses and the ultimate cost of paying claims reported on the policies and provide for a profit margin.
24090_13_ITEM7_P5_S1	For many of our insurance products, the Company is required to obtain approval for the premium rates from state insurance departments.
24090_13_ITEM7_P6_S0	The profitability of fixed annuities, riders and other spread-based product features depends largely on the Company s ability to earn target spreads between earned investment rates on assets and interest credited to policyholders.
24090_13_ITEM7_P7_S0	The investment return, or yield, on invested assets is an important element of the Company s earnings since insurance products are priced with the assumption that premiums received can be invested for a period of time before benefits are paid.
24090_13_ITEM7_P7_S1	The majority of the Company s invested assets have been held in available-for-sale and held-to-maturity securities, primarily in asset classes of corporate bonds, municipal bonds, and government obligation bonds.
24090_13_ITEM7_P8_S0	The current and projected low interest rate environment is having a significant impact on the determination of insurance contract liabilities and assets regarding reserves and deferred acquisition costs.
24090_13_ITEM7_P9_S0	The primary investment objective for the Company is to maximize economic value, consistent with acceptable risk parameters, including the management of credit risk and interest rate sensitivity of invested assets, while generating sufficient after-tax income to meet policyholder and corporate obligations.
24090_13_ITEM7_P9_S1	The Company maintains a conservative investment strategy that may vary based on a variety of factors including business needs, regulatory requirements and tax considerations.
24090_13_ITEM7_P10_S0	Our assets grew from $1.1 billion as of December 31, 2011 , to $1.2 billion as of December 31, 2012 .
24090_13_ITEM7_P10_S1	Total stockholders' equity increased from $248.0 million at December 31, 2011 , to $263.1 million at December 31, 2012 .
24090_13_ITEM7_P11_S0	Net investment income increased 5.4% and 3.0% for 2012 and 2011 , respectively, and was flat in 2010 .
24090_13_ITEM7_P11_S1	The average yield on the consolidated investment portfolio has declined significantly from a yield of 4.20% in 2010 down to 3.92% in 2011 and continued to decline at a more moderate pace to a yield of 3.81% in 2012 .
24090_13_ITEM7_P11_S2	The increase in the investment asset balances due to premium revenue growth was sufficient to offset the lower yield in the declining rate environment and resulted in an increase in net investment income.
24090_13_ITEM7_P12_S0	Realized net investment gains in the past three years resulted primarily from sales of securities that had been previously impaired due to declines in market values.
24090_13_ITEM7_P12_S1	These gains were partially offset by other-than-temporary impairments on investment securities and other long-term assets that were recorded in 2012 , 2011 and 2010 of $1,319,000 , $631,000 and $27,000 , respectively, reported as realized losses.

24090_13_ITEM7_P13_S1	In addition, death claims expense in the current year is higher compared to 2011 due to the release of incurred but unreported death claims liability in 2011 of $0.7 million.
24090_13_ITEM7_P14_S0	Changes in reserves resulted in liability increases from greater sales of endowment products that build up reserves at a faster pace than whole life longer term mortality based products.
24090_13_ITEM7_P14_S1	Additionally, the sustained low interest rate environment also results in a higher reserve development due to the lower interest yield assumptions in the current period compared to prior years.
24090_13_ITEM7_P15_S0	For over thirty-five years, CICA and its predecessors have accepted policy applications from foreign nationals for U.S. Dollar-denominated ordinary whole life insurance and endowment policies.
24090_13_ITEM7_P16_S0	We make our insurance products available using third-party marketing organizations and independent marketing consultants.
24090_13_ITEM7_P17_S0	Endowment product sales have been on the rise and represented approximately 81% of new sales.
24090_13_ITEM7_P17_S1	The Company offers a ten, fifteen and twenty year endowment and our top selling endowment is a product that matures at age sixty-five.
24090_13_ITEM7_P17_S2	We also introduced a new product in 2011 that is an endowment at age eighteen with a payout over four or five years.
24090_13_ITEM7_P18_S0	Through the domestic market of our Life Insurance segment, we provide ordinary whole life, credit life insurance, and final expense policies to middle and lower income families and individuals in certain markets in the mid-west and southern U.S.
24090_13_ITEM7_P18_S1	The majority of our domestic revenues are generated by the operations of domestic life insurance companies we have acquired since 1987.
24090_13_ITEM7_P19_S0	We provide final expense ordinary life insurance to middle and lower income individuals in Louisiana, Mississippi and Arkansas.
24090_13_ITEM7_P19_S1	Our policies in this segment are sold and serviced through a home service marketing distribution system utilizing employee-agents who work on a route system to collect premiums and service policyholders, and through networks of funeral homes that collect premiums and provide personal policyholder service.
24090_13_ITEM7_P20_S0	Significant economic issues impacting our business and industry currently and into the future are discussed below.
24090_13_ITEM7_P21_S0	It is predicted that the interest rate environment will remain low for the foreseeable future, which translates into lower profit margins for insurers.
24090_13_ITEM7_P22_S0	We have been impacted by the historically low interest rate environment over the past several years as our fixed income investment portfolio, primarily invested in callable securities, has been reinvested at lower yields.
24090_13_ITEM7_P22_S1	The Company s conservative investment strategy has not changed, but it has been a challenging investment time, as the large number of bond calls resulted in significant cash balances to be reinvested.
24090_13_ITEM7_P22_S2	The Company experienced some delays in reinvesting the funds as management identified suitable bonds meeting our target characteristics of investment grade and yield parameters were identified.
24090_13_ITEM7_P23_S0	Costs ( DAC ) balances, as assumptions are used in the development of the balances.
24090_13_ITEM7_P24_S0	Due to the recent decline in investment yields on our portfolio, our projection of long-term investment returns has declined.
24090_13_ITEM7_P24_S1	This has resulted in increasing the reserves on policies issued in the current year, as well as reducing the DAC asset.
24090_13_ITEM7_P25_S0	As an increasing percentage of the world population reaches retirement age, we believe we will benefit from increased demand for living products rather than death products, as aging baby boomers will require cash accumulation to pay expenses to meet their lifetime needs.
24090_13_ITEM7_P25_S1	Our ordinary life products are designed to accumulate cash values to provide for living expenses in a policy owner's later years, while continuously providing a death benefit.
24090_13_ITEM7_P26_S0	We believe there is a trend toward consolidation of domestic life insurance companies, due to significant losses incurred by the life insurance industry as a result of the credit crisis and recent economic pressures, as well as increasing costs of regulatory compliance for domestic life insurance companies.
24090_13_ITEM7_P26_S1	We believe this trend should be a benefit to our acquisition strategy as more complementary acquisition candidates may become available for us to consider.
24090_13_ITEM7_P27_S0	Many of the events and trends affecting the life insurance industry have had an impact on the life reinsurance industry.
24090_13_ITEM7_P27_S1	These events have led to a decline in the availability of reinsurance.
24090_13_ITEM7_P27_S2	While we currently cede a limited amount of our primary insurance business to reinsurers, we may find it difficult to obtain reinsurance in the future, forcing us to seek reinsurers who are more expensive to us.
24090_13_ITEM7_P27_S3	If we cannot obtain affordable reinsurance coverage, either our net exposures will increase or we will have to reduce our underwriting commitments.
24090_13_ITEM7_P28_S0	While our management has more than 40 years of experience in writing life insurance policies for foreign residents, changes related to foreign government laws and regulations and application of them, along with currency controls affecting our foreign resident insureds could adversely impact our revenues, results of operations and financial condition.
24090_13_ITEM7_P29_S0	In 2008, the Company acquired Ozark National Life Insurance Company ( ONLIC ), an Arkansas domiciled life company.
24090_13_ITEM7_P29_S1	This entity provided an Arkansas field force of home service agents and funeral homes selling pre-need and final expense policies and was merged into SPLIC as of October 1, 2009, and is included in the Home Service segment.
24090_13_ITEM7_P30_S0	In the first quarter of 2009, the Company completed its acquisition of Integrity Capital Corporation ("ICC").
24090_13_ITEM7_P30_S1	ICC is the parent of Integrity Capital Insurance Company ("ICIC"), an Indiana life insurance company.
24090_13_ITEM7_P30_S2	Both ICC and ICIC were merged into CICA effective April 1, 2011.

24090_13_ITEM7_P31_S1	At the time the agreements were executed, both companies were under receivership with the Louisiana Department of Insurance.

24090_13_ITEM7_P131_S0	We evaluate the carrying value of our fixed maturity and equity securities at least quarterly.
24090_13_ITEM7_P132_S0	The Company monitors all debt and equity securities on an on-going basis relative to changes in credit ratings, market prices, earnings trends and financial performance, in addition to specific region or industry reviews.
24090_13_ITEM7_P133_S0	The assessment of whether impairments have occurred is based on a case-by-case evaluation of underlying reasons for the decline in fair value.
24090_13_ITEM7_P134_S0	The Company determines other-than-temporary impairment ( OTTI ) by reviewing all relevant evidence related to the specific security issuer as well as the Company's intent to sell the security, or if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell a security before recovery of its amortized cost.
24090_13_ITEM7_P135_S0	When an OTTI has occurred, the amount of the OTTI recognized in earnings depends on whether the Company intends to sell the security or more likely than not will be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis.
24090_13_ITEM7_P135_S1	If the Company intends to sell the security or more likely than not will be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis, an OTTI is recognized in earnings equal to the entire difference between the investment's cost and its fair value at the balance sheet date.
24090_13_ITEM7_P135_S2	If the Company does not intend to sell the security and it is not more likely than not that the Company is required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis, the OTTI will be separated into the following: a) the amount representing the credit loss; and b) the amount related to all other factors.
24090_13_ITEM7_P135_S3	The amount of the total OTTI related to the credit loss is recognized in earnings.
24090_13_ITEM7_P135_S4	The amount of the total OTTI related to other factors is recognized in other comprehensive income, net of applicable taxes.
24090_13_ITEM7_P135_S5	The previous amortized cost basis less the OTTI recognized in earnings becomes the new amortized cost basis of the investment.
24090_13_ITEM7_P135_S6	The new amortized cost is not adjusted for subsequent recoveries in fair value.
24090_13_ITEM7_P136_S0	We recorded an OTTI write-down in 2012 of $1,319,000 related to one coal powered energy issuer debt security holding which has a maturity date in 2017.
24090_13_ITEM7_P137_S0	The operations of this energy provider have been negatively impacted by the challenging environment in the coal-fired generation sector and overall decline in the price of power it can charge to customers.
24090_13_ITEM7_P137_S1	The Company recorded an OTTI of $70,000 in 2011 related to one American Airlines bond holding, as the issuer filed for bankruptcy.

24090_13_ITEM7_P139_S0	As is customary among insurance companies, our insurance company subsidiaries reinsure with other companies portions of the life insurance risks they underwrite.
24090_13_ITEM7_P139_S1	A primary purpose of reinsurance agreements is to enable an insurance company to reduce the amount of risk on any particular life and, by reinsuring the amount exceeding the maximum amount the insurance company is willing to retain, to insure individuals in amounts larger than it could without such agreements.
24090_13_ITEM7_P139_S2	Even though a portion of the risk may be reinsured, our insurance company subsidiaries remain liable to perform all the obligations imposed by the policies issued by them and could be liable if their reinsurers were unable to meet their obligations under the reinsurance agreements.
24090_13_ITEM7_P140_S0	We believe we have established appropriate reinsurance coverage based upon our net retained insured liabilities compared to our surplus.
24090_13_ITEM7_P141_S0	The effect of reinsurance on premiums is as follows.
24090_13_ITEM7_P142_S0	Our insurance subsidiaries monitor the solvency of their reinsurers in seeking to minimize the risk of loss in the event of default by a reinsurer.
24090_13_ITEM7_P143_S0	The primary reinsurers of our insurance subsidiaries are large, well-capitalized entities.
24090_13_ITEM7_P144_S0	The effect of reinsurance on life insurance in force is as follows.

24090_13_ITEM7_P149_S0	Liquidity refers to a company's ability to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the needs of its operations.
24090_13_ITEM7_P149_S1	Liquidity is managed on insurance operations to ensure stable and reliable sources of cash flows to meet obligations and is provided by a variety of sources.
24090_13_ITEM7_P150_S0	Our liquidity requirements are met primarily by funds provided from operations.
24090_13_ITEM7_P150_S1	Premium deposits and revenues, investment income and investment maturities are the primary sources of funds, while investment purchases, policy benefits, and operating expenses are the primary uses of funds.
24090_13_ITEM7_P150_S2	We historically have not had to liquidate investments to provide cash flow, and there were no liquidity issues in 2012 or 2011 .
24090_13_ITEM7_P150_S3	Our investments consist of 87.9% of marketable debt securities and 5.5% of equity securities classified as available-for-sale that could be readily converted to cash for liquidity needs.
24090_13_ITEM7_P151_S0	A primary liquidity concern is the risk of an extraordinary level of early policyholder withdrawals.
24090_13_ITEM7_P151_S1	We include provisions within our insurance policies, such as surrender charges, that help limit and discourage early withdrawals.
24090_13_ITEM7_P151_S2	Since these contractual withdrawals, as well as the level of surrenders experienced, have been largely consistent with our assumptions in asset liability management, our associated cash outflows have, historically, not had an adverse impact on our overall liquidity.
24090_13_ITEM7_P152_S0	Individual life insurance policies are less susceptible to withdrawal than annuity reserves and deposit liabilities because policyholders may incur surrender charges and undergo a new underwriting process in order to obtain a new insurance policy.
24090_13_ITEM7_P152_S1	Cash flow projections and cash flow tests under various market interest rate scenarios are also performed annually to assist in evaluating liquidity needs and adequacy.
24090_13_ITEM7_P153_S0	We currently anticipate that available liquidity sources and future cash flows will be adequate to meet our needs for funds.
24090_13_ITEM7_P154_S0	Cash flows from our insurance operations historically have been sufficient to meet current needs.
24090_13_ITEM7_P154_S1	Cash flows from operating activities were $69.3 million , $64.3 million and $60.5 million for the years ended December 31, 2012 , 2011 and 2010 , respectively.
24090_13_ITEM7_P154_S2	We have traditionally also had significant cash flows from both scheduled and unscheduled fixed maturity security calls, maturities, redemptions, and prepayments, which totaled $326.7 million , $283.3 million and $387.4 million in 2012 , 2011 and 2010 .
24090_13_ITEM7_P154_S3	These cash flows, for the most part, are reinvested in fixed income securities.
24090_13_ITEM7_P154_S4	Net cash outflows from investment activity totaled $50.0 million , $85.1 million and $62.1 million for the years ended December 31, 2012 , 2011 and 2010 , respectively.
24090_13_ITEM7_P154_S5	The outflows from investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2012 , primarily related to the investment of excess cash and cash equivalents generated from operations during 2012 .
24090_13_ITEM7_P154_S6	The Company's cash flows from financing activities were $3.8 million in 2012 , $4.3 million in 2011 and $2.6 million in 2010 .
24090_13_ITEM7_P155_S0	The NAIC has established minimum capital requirements in the form of RBC.
24090_13_ITEM7_P155_S1	RBC considers the type of business written by an insurance company, the quality of its assets, and various other aspects of an insurance company's business to develop a minimum level of capital called "Authorized Control Level Risk-based Capital" and compares this level to an adjusted statutory capital that includes capital and surplus as reported under statutory accounting principles, plus certain investment reserves.
24090_13_ITEM7_P155_S2	Should the ratio of adjusted statutory capital to control level risk-based capital fall below 200%, a series of remedial actions by the affected company would be required.
24090_13_ITEM7_P156_S0	At December 31, 2012 , all of our insurance subsidiaries were above the required minimum RBC levels.
24090_13_ITEM7_P157_S0	In 2011 , CICA contributed 150,000 shares of Citizens, Inc.
24090_13_ITEM7_P157_S1	Class A common stock to CNLIC as a capital contribution due to minimum capital and surplus considerations.
24090_13_ITEM7_P157_S2	The contributed shares had a fair market contributed value of $1.1 million .
24090_13_ITEM7_P158_S0	Class A Common shares in 2012 from CTI with an approximate fair value of $0.5 million.
24090_13_ITEM7_P158_S1	These transactions have been eliminated under consolidation accounting rules.

24090_13_ITEM7_P160_S0	The payments related to the future policy benefits and policy claims payable reflected in the table above have been projected utilizing assumptions based upon our historical experience and anticipated future experience.
24090_13_ITEM7_P161_S0	The Company does not have off-balance sheet arrangements at December 31, 2012 and, therefore, does not expect any future effects on the Company's financial condition related to any such arrangements.
24090_13_ITEM7_P162_S0	We do not utilize special purpose entities as investment vehicles, nor are there any such entities in which we have an investment that engages in speculative activities of any nature, and we do not use such investments to hedge our investment positions.
24090_13_ITEM7_P163_S0	Citizens is a holding company and has had minimal operations of its own.
24090_13_ITEM7_P163_S1	Our assets consist of the capital stock of our subsidiaries, cash, fixed income securities, mutual funds and investment real estate.
24090_13_ITEM7_P163_S2	Our cash flows depend primarily upon the availability of statutorily permissible payments, primarily payments under management agreements from our two primary life insurance subsidiaries, CICA and SPLIC.
24090_13_ITEM7_P163_S3	The ability to make payments is limited by applicable laws and regulations of Colorado, CICA's state of domicile, and Louisiana, SPLIC's state of domicile, which subject insurance operations to significant regulatory restrictions.
24090_13_ITEM7_P163_S4	These laws and regulations require, among other things, that these insurance subsidiaries maintain minimum solvency requirements and limit the amount of dividends these subsidiaries can pay to the holding company.
24090_13_ITEM7_P164_S0	We historically have not relied upon dividends from subsidiaries for our cash flow needs.
24090_13_ITEM7_P164_S1	However, CICA and SPLIC both dividend available funds from time to time in relation to new acquisition target strategies.
24090_13_ITEM7_P165_S0	CICA has contributed amounts in the form of dividends to Citizens totaling $5.4 million , $6.8 million and $9.3 million in 2012 , 2011 and 2010 , respectively.
24090_13_ITEM7_P166_S0	Additionally, a substantial portion of our international policyholders invest their policy cash dividends and benefits in our Class A common stock through our Stock Investment Plan (the Plan ).
24090_13_ITEM7_P166_S1	Once a policyholder elects to participate in the Plan, their policy benefits can be used to purchase Citizens Class A common stock through the Plan in the open market.
24090_13_ITEM7_P166_S2	In addition, our existing holders of Class A common stock, our employees and our independent consultants are eligible to participate in the Plan.
24090_13_ITEM7_P166_S3	If fewer policyholders elect to participate in the Plan, or if our international premium collections were to decrease as a result of regulatory or marketing impediments, the trading volume of our Class A common stock may decline from its present levels.
24090_13_ITEM7_P167_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect reported amounts and related disclosures.
24090_13_ITEM7_P167_S1	Management considers an accounting estimate to be critical if: (1) it requires assumptions to be made that were uncertain at the time the estimate was made; and (2) changes in the estimate, or different estimates that could have been selected, could have a material effect on our consolidated results of operations or financial condition.
24090_13_ITEM7_P167_S2	While we believe that our estimates, assumptions, and judgments are reasonable, they are based on information presently available.
24090_13_ITEM7_P167_S3	Additionally, changes in our assumptions, estimates or assessments as a result of unforeseen events or otherwise could have a material impact on our financial position or results of operations.
24090_13_ITEM7_P168_S0	Management has discussed the development and selection of its critical accounting estimates with the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors, and the Audit Committee has reviewed the disclosure presented below relating to them.
24090_13_ITEM7_P169_S0	No. 1, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies, of the Notes to our Financial Statements for further information on our critical accounting policies.
24090_13_ITEM7_P170_S0	Our critical accounting policies are as follows:
24090_13_ITEM7_P171_S0	Future policy benefit reserves have been computed by the net level premium method with assumptions as to investment yields, dividends on participating business, mortality and withdrawals based upon our experience.
24090_13_ITEM7_P171_S1	The preparation of financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of policy liabilities and the increase in future policy benefit reserves.
24090_13_ITEM7_P171_S2	Management's judgments and estimates for future policy benefit reserves provide for possible unfavorable deviation.
24090_13_ITEM7_P172_S0	We continue to use the original assumptions (including a provision for the risk of adverse deviation) in subsequent periods to determine the changes in the liability for future policy benefits (the "lock-in concept ) unless a premium deficiency exists.
24090_13_ITEM7_P172_S1	Management monitors these assumptions and has determined that a premium deficiency did not exist as of December 31, 2012 .
24090_13_ITEM7_P172_S2	Management believes that our policy liabilities and increase in future policy benefit reserves as of the years ended December 31, 2012 , 2011 and 2010 are based upon assumptions, including a provision for the risk of adverse deviation, that do not warrant revision.
24090_13_ITEM7_P173_S0	Acquisition costs, consisting of commissions and policy issuance, underwriting and agency expenses that relate to and vary with the successful production of new business, are deferred.
24090_13_ITEM7_P173_S1	These deferred policy acquisition costs are amortized primarily over the estimated premium paying period of the related policies in proportion to the ratio of the annual premium recognized to the total premium revenue anticipated, using the same assumptions as were used in computing liabilities for future policy benefits.
24090_13_ITEM7_P174_S0	We utilize the factor method to determine the amount of costs to be capitalized and the ending asset balance.
24090_13_ITEM7_P174_S1	The factor method is based on the ratio of premium revenue recognized for the policies in force at the end of each reporting period compared to the premium revenue recognized for policies in force at the beginning of the reporting period.
24090_13_ITEM7_P174_S2	The factor method ensures that policies that lapsed or surrendered during the reporting period are no longer included in the deferred policy acquisition costs calculation.
24090_13_ITEM7_P174_S3	The factor method limits the amount of deferred costs to its estimated realizable value, provided actual experience is comparable to that contemplated in the factors.
24090_13_ITEM7_P175_S0	Inherent in the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs are certain management judgments about what acquisition costs are deferred, the ending asset balance and the annual amortization.
24090_13_ITEM7_P175_S1	Approximately 90.0% of our capitalized deferred acquisition costs are attributed to first year excess commissions.
24090_13_ITEM7_P175_S2	The remaining 10.0% are attributed to costs that vary with and are directly related to the successful acquisition of new insurance business.
24090_13_ITEM7_P175_S3	Those costs generally include costs related to the production, underwriting and issuance of new business.
24090_13_ITEM7_P176_S0	A recoverability test that considers, among other things, actual experience and projected future experience is performed at least annually.
24090_13_ITEM7_P176_S1	These annual recoverability tests initially calculate the available premium (gross premium less benefit and expense portion of premium) for the next 30 years.
24090_13_ITEM7_P176_S2	The available premium per policy and the deferred policy acquisition costs per policy are then calculated.
24090_13_ITEM7_P176_S3	The deferred policy acquisition costs are then evaluated over two methods utilizing reasonable assumptions and two other methods using pessimistic assumptions.
24090_13_ITEM7_P177_S0	The two methods utilizing pessimistic assumptions still support early recoverability of our aggregate deferred policy acquisition costs.
24090_13_ITEM7_P178_S0	Management believes that our deferred policy acquisition costs and related amortization for the years ended December 31, 2012 , 2011 and 2010 limits the amount of deferred costs to its estimated realizable value.
24090_13_ITEM7_P178_S1	This belief is based upon the analysis performed on capitalized expenses that vary with and are primarily related to the acquisition of new and renewal insurance business, utilization of the factor method and annual recoverability testing.
24090_13_ITEM7_P179_S0	Cost of Customer Relationships Acquired ("CCRA") is established when we purchase a block of insurance.
24090_13_ITEM7_P179_S1	CCRA is amortized primarily over the emerging profit of the related policies using the same assumptions as were used in computing liabilities for future policy benefits.
24090_13_ITEM7_P180_S0	We utilize various methods to determine the amount of the ending asset balance, including a static model and a dynamic model.
24090_13_ITEM7_P180_S1	Inherent in the amortization of CCRA are certain management judgments about the ending asset balance and the annual amortization.
24090_13_ITEM7_P180_S2	The assumptions used are based upon interest, mortality and lapses at the time of purchase.
24090_13_ITEM7_P181_S0	A recoverability test that considers, among other things, actual experience and projected future experience is performed at least annually.
24090_13_ITEM7_P181_S1	These annual recoverability tests initially calculate the available premium (gross premium less benefit and expense portion of premium) for the next thirty years.
24090_13_ITEM7_P181_S2	The CCRA is then evaluated utilizing reasonable assumptions.
24090_13_ITEM7_P181_S3	Management believes our CCRA and related amortization is recoverable for the years ended December 31, 2012 , 2011 and 2010 .
24090_13_ITEM7_P181_S4	This belief is based upon the analysis performed on estimated future results of the block and our annual recoverability testing.
24090_13_ITEM7_P182_S0	Current accounting guidance requires that goodwill balances be reviewed for impairment at least annually or more frequently if events occur or circumstances change that would indicate that a triggering event has occurred.
24090_13_ITEM7_P183_S0	A reporting unit is defined as an operating segment on one level below an operating segment.
24090_13_ITEM7_P183_S1	Most of the Company's reporting units, for which goodwill has been allocated, are equivalent to the Company's operating segment, as there is no discrete financial information available for the separate components of the segment or all of the components of the segment have similar economic characteristics.
24090_13_ITEM7_P184_S0	The goodwill impairment test follows a multi step process as defined under current accounting guidance.
24090_13_ITEM7_P184_S1	An initial review may be performed whereby the assessment is based upon a qualitative factors before performing the first test step.
24090_13_ITEM7_P185_S0	In the first step, the fair value of a reporting unit is compared to its carrying value.
24090_13_ITEM7_P185_S1	If the carrying value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the impairment test is performed for purposes of measuring the impairment.
24090_13_ITEM7_P185_S2	In the second step, the fair value of the reporting unit is allocated to all of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit to determine an implied goodwill value.
24090_13_ITEM7_P185_S3	If the carrying amount of the reporting unit goodwill exceeds the implied goodwill value, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to that excess.
24090_13_ITEM7_P186_S0	Management's determination of the fair value of each reporting unit incorporates multiple inputs including discounted cash flow calculations, peer company price to earnings multiples, the level of the Company's Class A common stock price and assumptions that market participants would make in valuing the reporting unit.
24090_13_ITEM7_P186_S1	Other assumptions can include levels of economic capital, future business growth, and earnings projections.
24090_13_ITEM7_P187_S0	The evaluation of securities for impairments is a quantitative and qualitative process, which is subject to risks and uncertainties and is intended to determine whether declines in the fair value of investments should be recognized in current period earnings.
24090_13_ITEM7_P187_S1	The risks and uncertainties include changes in general economic conditions, the issuer's financial condition or future prospects, the effects of changes in interest rates or credit spreads and the expected recovery period.
24090_13_ITEM7_P188_S0	Based upon current accounting guidance, investment securities must be classified as held-to-maturity, available-for-sale or trading.
24090_13_ITEM7_P188_S1	Management determines the appropriate classification at the time of purchase.
24090_13_ITEM7_P189_S0	The classification of securities is significant since it directly impacts the accounting for unrealized gains and losses on securities.
24090_13_ITEM7_P189_S1	Fixed maturity securities are classified as held-to-maturity and carried at amortized cost when management has the positive intent and the Company has the ability to hold the securities to maturity.
24090_13_ITEM7_P189_S2	Securities not classified as held-to-maturity are classified as available-for-sale and are carried at fair value, with the unrealized holding gains and losses, net of tax, reported in other comprehensive income and do not affect earnings until realized.
24090_13_ITEM7_P190_S0	The Company evaluates all securities on a quarterly basis, and more frequently when economic conditions warrant additional evaluations, for determining if an OTTI exists pursuant to the accounting guidelines.
24090_13_ITEM7_P190_S1	In evaluating the possible impairment of securities, consideration is given to the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has been less than cost, the financial conditions and near-term prospects of the issuer, and the ability and intent of the Company to retain its investment in the issuer for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in fair value.
24090_13_ITEM7_P190_S2	In analyzing an issuer's financial condition, the Company may consider whether the securities are issued by the Federal government or its agencies, by government-sponsored agencies, or whether downgrades by bond rating agencies have occurred, and reviews of the issuer's financial condition.
24090_13_ITEM7_P191_S0	If management determines that an investment experienced an OTTI, management must then determine the amount of OTTI to be recognized in earnings.
24090_13_ITEM7_P191_S1	If management does not intend to sell the security and it is more likely than not that the Company will not be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period loss, the OTTI will be separated into the amount representing the credit loss and the amount related to all other factors.
24090_13_ITEM7_P191_S2	The amount of OTTI related to the credit loss is determined based on the present value of cash flows expected to be collected and is recognized in earnings.
24090_13_ITEM7_P191_S3	The amount of OTTI related to other factors will be recognized in other comprehensive income, net of applicable taxes.
24090_13_ITEM7_P191_S4	The previous amortized cost basis less the OTTI recognized in earnings will become the new amortized cost basis of the investment.
24090_13_ITEM7_P191_S5	If management intends to sell the security or more likely than not will be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period credit loss, the OTTI will be recognized in earnings equal to the entire difference between the investment's amortized cost basis and its fair value at the balance sheet date.
24090_13_ITEM7_P191_S6	Any recoveries related to the value of these securities are recorded as an unrealized gain (as other comprehensive income (loss) in shareholders' equity) and not recognized in income until the security is ultimately sold.
24090_13_ITEM7_P192_S0	The Company from time to time may dispose of an impaired security in response to asset/liability management decisions, future market movements, business plan changes, or if the net proceeds can be reinvested at a rate of return that is expected to recover the loss within a reasonable period of time.
24090_13_ITEM7_P193_S0	Premiums on life and accident and health policies are reported as earned when due or, for short duration contracts, over the contract period on a pro rata basis.
24090_13_ITEM7_P193_S1	Benefits and expenses are associated with earned premiums so as to result in recognition of profits over the estimated life of the contracts.
24090_13_ITEM7_P193_S2	This matching is accomplished by means of provisions for future benefits and the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs.
24090_13_ITEM7_P194_S0	Annuities are accounted for in a manner consistent with accounting for interest bearing financial instruments.
24090_13_ITEM7_P195_S0	Our primary annuity products do not include fees or other such charges.
24090_13_ITEM7_P196_S0	A deferred tax asset or deferred tax liability is recorded only if a determination is made that it is more-likely-than-not that the tax treatment on which the deferred tax item depends will be sustained in the event of an audit.
24090_13_ITEM7_P196_S1	These determinations inherently involve management's judgment.
24090_13_ITEM7_P196_S2	In addition, the Company must record a tax valuation allowance with respect to deferred tax assets if it is more-likely-than-not that the tax benefit will not be realized.
24090_13_ITEM7_P196_S3	This valuation allowance is in essence a contra account to the deferred tax asset.
24090_13_ITEM7_P196_S4	Management must determine the portion of the deferred tax asset and resulting tax benefit that may not be realized based upon judgment of expected outcomes.
24090_13_ITEM7_P197_S0	Due to significant estimates utilized in establishing the valuation allowance and the potential for changes in facts and circumstances, it is reasonably possible that we will be required to record a valuation allowance in future reporting periods.
24090_13_ITEM7_P197_S1	Such a charge could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and capital position.
24090_13_ITEM7_P198_S0	Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, Note 1.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The nature of our business exposes us to market risk relative to our invested assets and policy liabilities.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Market risk is the risk of loss that may occur when changes in interest rates and public equity prices adversely affect the value of our invested assets.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Interest rate risk is our primary market risk exposure.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P0_S3	Substantial and sustained increases and decreases in market interest rates can affect the fair value of our investments.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P0_S4	The fair value of our fixed maturity portfolio generally increases when interest rates decrease and decreases when interest rates increase.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The following table summarizes net unrealized gains and losses for the periods indicated.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Our exposure to interest rate changes results from our significant holdings of fixed maturity investments, policy loans and mortgage loans on real estate, all of which comprised over 87.3% of our cash and investment portfolio as of December 31, 2012 .
24090_13_ITEM7A_P2_S1	These investments are mainly exposed to changes in U.S. Treasury rates.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Our fixed maturities investments include U.S. Government-sponsored enterprises, U.S. Government bonds, securities issued by government agencies, state and municipal bonds, and corporate bonds.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Approximately 16.9% of the fixed maturities we owned at market value on December 31, 2012 are instruments of U.S. Government-sponsored enterprises, or are backed by U.S. Government agencies.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P3_S0	To manage interest risk, we perform periodic projections of asset and liability cash flows to evaluate the potential sensitivity of our investments and liabilities.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P4_S0	We assess interest rate sensitivity on an annual basis with respect to our fixed maturities investments using hypothetical test scenarios that assume either upward or downward shifts in the prevailing interest rates.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P4_S1	The Company performed an analysis of fair values changes using assumed 100 basis point upward shifts in interest rates, noting that the fair value of our fixed maturity investment portfolio of $798.3 million would decrease approximately $58.1 million to a fair value of $740.2 million upon a 100 basis point increase.

24090_13_ITEM7A_P5_S0	While the test scenarios are for illustrative purposes only and do not reflect our expectations regarding future interest rates or the performance of fixed-income markets, it is a near-term change that illustrates the potential impact of such events.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P6_S0	Due to the composition of our book of insurance business, we believe it is unlikely we would encounter large surrender activity due to an interest rate increase that would force us to dispose of our fixed maturities at a loss.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P7_S0	Our fixed maturity portfolio is exposed to call risk as a significant portion of the current holdings are callable.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P7_S1	A decreasing interest rate environment can result in increased call activity as experienced over the past several years, and an increasing rate environment will likely result in securities being paid at their stated maturity.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P8_S0	There are no fixed maturities or other investments that we classify as trading instruments.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P8_S1	Approximately 75.7% of fixed maturities were held in available-for-sale and 24.3% in held-to-maturity based upon fair value at December 31, 2012 .
24090_13_ITEM7A_P8_S2	At December 31, 2012 and 2011 , we had no investments in derivative instruments, subprime loans or CDOs (collateralized debt obligations).
24090_13_ITEM7A_P9_S0	Changes in the level or volatility of equity prices affect the value of equity securities we hold as investments.
24090_13_ITEM7A_P9_S1	Our equity investments portfolio represented 5.6% of our total investments at December 31, 2012 , with 95.7% invested in diversified equity and bond mutual funds.

24090_13_ITEM9A_P8_S0	A company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
24090_13_ITEM9A_P8_S1	A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
24090_13_ITEM9A_P9_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
24090_13_ITEM9A_P9_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
24090_13_ITEM9A_P10_S0	In our opinion, Citizens, Inc. and subsidiaries maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2012, based on the COSO criteria.

24090_13_ITEM15_P3_S1	Our audit also included the financial statement schedules II, III, and IV under Item 15 of the Index.
24090_13_ITEM15_P3_S2	These financial statements and schedules are the responsibility of the Company's management.
24090_13_ITEM15_P3_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements and schedules based on our audits.
24090_13_ITEM15_P4_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
24090_13_ITEM15_P4_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
24090_13_ITEM15_P5_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
24090_13_ITEM15_P5_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
24090_13_ITEM15_P5_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.

24090_13_ITEM15_P6_S1	Also, in our opinion, the related financial statement schedules, when considered in relation to the basic financial statements taken as a whole, present fairly in all material respects the information set forth therein.

24090_13_ITEM15_P21_S0	The accompanying consolidated financial statements of Citizens, Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries have been prepared in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles ("U.S. GAAP").
24090_13_ITEM15_P22_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts and operations of Citizens, Inc. ("Citizens"), a Colorado corporation, and its wholly-owned subsidiaries, CICA Life Insurance Company of America ("CICA"), Citizens National Life Insurance Company ("CNLIC"), Security Plan Life Insurance Company ("SPLIC"), Security Plan Fire Insurance Company ("SPFIC"), Computing Technology, Inc. ("CTI"), and Insurance Investors, Inc. ("III").
24090_13_ITEM15_P22_S1	All significant inter-company accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
24090_13_ITEM15_P23_S0	We provide primarily life insurance, as well as a small amount of health insurance policies, through three of our subsidiaries - CICA, SPLIC, and CNLIC.
24090_13_ITEM15_P24_S0	CICA and CNLIC issue ordinary whole-life policies, burial insurance, pre-need policies, and accident and health related policies, throughout the Midwest and southern United States.
24090_13_ITEM15_P24_S1	CICA also issues ordinary whole-life policies to non-U.S. residents.
24090_13_ITEM15_P25_S0	SPLIC offers final expense and home service life insurance in Louisiana, Arkansas and Mississippi and SPFIC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of SPLIC, writes a limited amount of property insurance in Louisiana.
24090_13_ITEM15_P26_S0	CTI provides data processing systems and services, as well as furniture and equipment, to the Company.
24090_13_ITEM15_P27_S0	III provides aviation transportation to the Company.
24090_13_ITEM15_P28_S0	Investment securities are classified as held-to-maturity, available-for-sale or trading.
24090_13_ITEM15_P28_S1	Management determines the appropriate classification at the time of purchase.
24090_13_ITEM15_P29_S0	The classification of securities is significant since it directly impacts the accounting for unrealized gains and losses on securities.
24090_13_ITEM15_P29_S1	Fixed maturity securities are classified as held-to-maturity and carried at amortized cost when management has the positive intent and the Company has the ability to hold the securities to maturity.
24090_13_ITEM15_P29_S2	Securities not classified as held-to-maturity are classified as available-for-sale and are carried at fair value, with the unrealized holding gains and losses, net of tax, reported in other comprehensive income and do not affect earnings until realized.
24090_13_ITEM15_P30_S0	Fixed maturities consist primarily of bonds classified as available-for-sale or held-to-maturity.
24090_13_ITEM15_P30_S1	The Company does not classify any fixed maturities as trading.
24090_13_ITEM15_P30_S2	Equity securities (including non-redeemable preferred stock) are considered available-for-sale and are reported at fair value.
24090_13_ITEM15_P31_S0	Unrealized appreciation (depreciation) of equity securities and fixed maturities held as available-for-sale is shown as a separate component of stockholders' equity, net of tax, and is a separate component of comprehensive income.
24090_13_ITEM15_P32_S0	The Company evaluates all securities on a quarterly basis, and more frequently when economic conditions warrant additional evaluations, for determining if an other-than-temporary impairment ("OTTI") exists pursuant to the accounting guidelines.
24090_13_ITEM15_P32_S1	In evaluating the possible impairment of securities, consideration is given to the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has been less than cost, the financial conditions and near-term prospects of the issuer, and the ability and intent of the Company to retain its investment in the issuer for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in fair value.
24090_13_ITEM15_P32_S2	In analyzing an issuer s financial condition, the Company may consider whether the securities are issued by the Federal government or its agencies, by government-sponsored agencies, or whether downgrades by bond rating agencies have occurred, and reviews of the issuer s financial condition.
24090_13_ITEM15_P33_S0	If management determines that an investment experienced an OTTI, management must then determine the amount of OTTI to be recognized in earnings.
24090_13_ITEM15_P33_S1	If management does not intend to sell the security and it is more likely than not that the Company will not be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period loss, the OTTI will be separated into the amount representing the credit loss and the amount related to all other factors.
24090_13_ITEM15_P33_S2	The amount of OTTI related to the credit loss is determined based on the present value of cash flows expected to be collected and is recognized in earnings.
24090_13_ITEM15_P34_S0	The previous amortized cost basis less the OTTI recognized in earnings will become the new amortized cost basis of the investment.
24090_13_ITEM15_P34_S1	If management intends to sell the security or more likely than not will be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period credit loss, the OTTI will be recognized in earnings equal to the entire difference between the investment's amortized cost basis and its fair value at the balance sheet date.
24090_13_ITEM15_P34_S2	Any recoveries related to the value of these securities are recorded as an unrealized gain (as other comprehensive income (loss) in stockholders' equity) and not recognized in income until the security is ultimately sold.
24090_13_ITEM15_P35_S0	The Company from time to time may dispose of an impaired security in response to asset/liability management decisions, future market movements, business plan changes, or if the net proceeds can be reinvested at a rate of return that is expected to recover the loss within a reasonable period of time.
24090_13_ITEM15_P36_S0	Mortgage loans on real estate and policy loans are reported at unpaid principal balances.
24090_13_ITEM15_P37_S0	Real estate and other long-term investments consist primarily of land and buildings that are recorded at depreciated cost.
24090_13_ITEM15_P37_S1	If the fair value of the real estate is less than the carrying value, an impairment loss is recognized and charged to earnings.
24090_13_ITEM15_P38_S0	Premiums and discounts are amortized or accreted over the life of the related security as an adjustment to yield using the effective interest method.
24090_13_ITEM15_P39_S0	Dividend and interest income is recognized when earned.
24090_13_ITEM15_P39_S1	Realized gains and losses are included in earnings and are derived using the specific identification method for determining the cost of securities sold.
24090_13_ITEM15_P40_S0	The Company had cash equivalents and fixed maturities with an aggregate fair value of $10.2 million and $10.5 million at December 31, 2012 and 2011 , respectively, on deposit with various state regulatory authorities to fulfill statutory requirements.
24090_13_ITEM15_P41_S0	Premiums on life policies are recognized as earned when due.
24090_13_ITEM15_P41_S1	Due premiums on the balance sheet are net of allowances.
24090_13_ITEM15_P42_S0	Accident and health policies are recognized as revenue over the contract period on a pro rata basis.
24090_13_ITEM15_P42_S1	Benefits and expenses are associated with earned premiums so as to result in the recognition of profits over the estimated lives of the contracts.
24090_13_ITEM15_P42_S2	This matching is accomplished by means of a provision for future policy benefits and the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs.
24090_13_ITEM15_P43_S0	Annuity policies, primarily flexible premium fixed annuity products, are accounted for in a manner consistent with accounting for interest bearing financial instruments.
24090_13_ITEM15_P43_S1	Premium receipts are not reported as revenue, rather as deposit liabilities to annuity contracts.
24090_13_ITEM15_P43_S2	The annuity products issued do not include fees or other such charges.
24090_13_ITEM15_P44_S0	Acquisition costs, consisting of commissions and policy issuance, underwriting and agent convention expenses that are primarily related to and vary with the successful production of new and renewal business, have been deferred.
24090_13_ITEM15_P44_S1	These deferred amounts, referred to as deferred policy acquisition costs ("DAC"), are recorded as an asset on the balance sheet and amortized to income in a systematic manner, based on related contract revenues or gross profits as appropriate.
24090_13_ITEM15_P45_S0	Traditional life insurance and accident and health insurance acquisition costs are being amortized over the premium paying period of the related policies using assumptions consistent with those used in computing future policy benefit liabilities.
24090_13_ITEM15_P45_S1	For universal life type contracts and investment contracts that include significant surrender charges or that yield significant revenues from sources other than the investment contract holders' funds, the deferred contract acquisition cost amortization is matched to the recognition of gross profit.
24090_13_ITEM15_P45_S2	The effect on the DAC asset that would result from realization of unrealized gains or losses is recognized with an offset to accumulated other comprehensive income in consolidated stockholders' equity.
24090_13_ITEM15_P46_S0	If an internal replacement of insurance or investment contract modification substantially changes a contract as defined in current accounting guidance, then the DAC is written off immediately through income and any new deferrable costs associated with the new replacement are deferred.
24090_13_ITEM15_P46_S1	If a contract modification does not substantially change the contract, the DAC amortization on the original contract will continue and any acquisition costs associated with the related modification are immediately expensed.
24090_13_ITEM15_P47_S0	We utilize the factor method to determine the amount of costs to be capitalized and the ending asset balance.
24090_13_ITEM15_P47_S1	The factor method is based on the ratio of premium revenue recognized for the policies in force at the end of each reporting period compared to the premium revenue recognized for policies in force at the beginning of the reporting period.
24090_13_ITEM15_P47_S2	The factor method ensures that policies lapsed or surrendered during the reporting period are no longer included in the deferred policy acquisition costs calculation.
24090_13_ITEM15_P47_S3	The factor method limits the amount of deferred costs to its estimated realizable value, provided actual experience is comparable to that contemplated in the factors.
24090_13_ITEM15_P48_S0	Inherent in the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs are certain management judgments about what acquisition costs are deferred, the ending asset balance and the annual amortization.
24090_13_ITEM15_P48_S1	Approximately 90% of our capitalized deferred acquisition costs are attributed to first year excess commissions.
24090_13_ITEM15_P48_S2	The remaining 10% are attributed to costs that vary with and are directly related to the acquisition of new insurance business.
24090_13_ITEM15_P48_S3	Those costs generally include costs related to the production, underwriting and issuance of new business.
24090_13_ITEM15_P49_S0	A recoverability test that considers, among other things, actual experience and projected future experience is performed at least annually.
24090_13_ITEM15_P49_S1	These annual recoverability tests initially calculate the available premium (gross premium less the benefit and expense portion of premium) for the next 30 years.
24090_13_ITEM15_P49_S2	The available premium per policy and the deferred policy acquisition costs per policy are then calculated.
24090_13_ITEM15_P49_S3	The deferred policy acquisition costs are then evaluated over two methods utilizing reasonable assumptions and two other methods using pessimistic assumptions.
24090_13_ITEM15_P50_S0	Management believes that our deferred policy acquisition costs and related amortization for the years ended December 31, 2012 , 2011 and 2010 limits the amount of deferred costs to its estimated realizable value.
24090_13_ITEM15_P50_S1	This belief is based upon the analysis performed on capitalized expenses that vary with and are primarily related to the acquisition of new and renewal insurance business, utilization of the factor method and annual recoverability testing.
24090_13_ITEM15_P51_S0	The components of deferred acquisition costs from year to year are summarized as follows:
24090_13_ITEM15_P52_S0	Cost of customer relationships acquired ("CCRA") is established when we purchase a block of insurance.
24090_13_ITEM15_P52_S1	CCRA is amortized primarily over the emerging profit of the related policies using the same assumptions as were used in computing liabilities for future policy benefits.
24090_13_ITEM15_P53_S0	We utilize various methods to determine the amount of the ending asset balance, including a static model and a dynamic model.
24090_13_ITEM15_P53_S1	Inherent in the amortization of CCRA are certain management judgments about the ending asset balance and the annual amortization.
24090_13_ITEM15_P53_S2	The assumptions used are based upon interest, mortality and lapses at the time of purchase.
24090_13_ITEM15_P54_S0	A recoverability test that considers, among other things, actual experience and projected future experience is performed at least annually.
24090_13_ITEM15_P54_S1	These annual recoverability tests initially calculate the available premium (gross premium less the benefit and expense portion of premium) for the next thirty years.
24090_13_ITEM15_P54_S2	The CCRA is then evaluated utilizing reasonable assumptions.
24090_13_ITEM15_P54_S3	Management believes that our CCRA and related amortization is recoverable for the years ended December 31, 2012 , 2011 and 2010 .
24090_13_ITEM15_P54_S4	This belief is based upon the analysis performed on estimated future results of the block and our annual recoverability testing.

24090_13_ITEM15_P56_S0	Estimated amortization of cost of customer relationship acquired in each of the next five years and thereafter is as follows.
24090_13_ITEM15_P56_S1	Actual future amortization will differ from these estimates due to variances from estimated future withdrawal assumptions.
24090_13_ITEM15_P57_S0	The value of CCRA in our various acquisitions, which is included in cost of customer relationships acquired in the accompanying consolidated financial statements, was determined based on the present value of future profits discounted at annual rates ranging from 4.5% to 8.5% .
24090_13_ITEM15_P58_S0	Future policy benefit reserves for traditional life insurance and accident and health insurance contract benefits and expenses are computed using a net level premium method, with assumptions as to investment yields, dividends on participating business, mortality and withdrawals based upon our experience, modified as necessary to reflect anticipated trends and to include provisions for possible unfavorable deviations.
24090_13_ITEM15_P59_S0	The accrued account balance for non-traditional life insurance and investment contracts is computed as deposits net of withdrawals made by the contract holder, plus amounts credited based on contract specifications, less contract fees and charges assessed, plus any additional interest.
24090_13_ITEM15_P59_S1	Annuity interest crediting rates range from 3.0% to 5.5% annually.
24090_13_ITEM15_P59_S2	Benefits and expenses are charged against the account balance to recognize costs as incurred over the estimated lives of the contracts.
24090_13_ITEM15_P59_S3	Expenses include interest credited to contract account balances and benefits paid in excess of contract account balances.
24090_13_ITEM15_P60_S0	Unpaid claims on accident and health policies represent the estimated liability for benefit expenses, both reported but not paid and incurred but not reported to the Company.
24090_13_ITEM15_P60_S1	Liabilities for unpaid claims are estimated using individual case basis valuations and statistical analyses.
24090_13_ITEM15_P60_S2	Those estimates are subject to the effects of trends in claim severity and frequency.
24090_13_ITEM15_P61_S0	Anticipated investment income is not considered in determining whether a premium deficiency exists with respect to short-duration contracts.
24090_13_ITEM15_P62_S0	Premium deposits accrue interest at rates ranging from 4.0% to 8.25% per annum.
24090_13_ITEM15_P62_S1	The cost of insurance is included in the premium when collected and interest is credited annually to deposit accounts.
24090_13_ITEM15_P63_S0	The development of liabilities for future policy benefits requires management to make estimates and assumptions regarding mortality, morbidity, lapse, expense, and investment experience.
24090_13_ITEM15_P63_S1	These estimates are based primarily on historical experience and future expectations of mortality, morbidity, expense, persistency, and investment assumptions.
24090_13_ITEM15_P63_S2	Actual results could differ materially from estimates.
24090_13_ITEM15_P63_S3	We monitor actual experience and revise assumptions as necessary.
24090_13_ITEM15_P64_S0	Goodwill is the difference between the purchase price in a business combination and the fair value of assets and liabilities acquired, and is not amortized.
24090_13_ITEM15_P64_S1	Other intangible assets include various state insurance licenses, which have been determined to have indefinite useful lives and, therefore, are not amortized.
24090_13_ITEM15_P64_S2	Both goodwill and other intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are subject to annual impairment analyses.
24090_13_ITEM15_P65_S0	The goodwill impairment test uses a two step process as set forth under current accounting guidance.
24090_13_ITEM15_P65_S1	In the first step, the fair value of a reporting unit is compared to its carrying value.
24090_13_ITEM15_P65_S2	If the carrying value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the impairment test is performed for purposes of measuring the impairment.
24090_13_ITEM15_P65_S3	In the second step, the fair value of the reporting unit is allocated to all of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit to determine an implied goodwill value.
24090_13_ITEM15_P65_S4	If the carrying amount of the reporting unit goodwill exceeds the implied goodwill value, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to that excess.
24090_13_ITEM15_P66_S0	Management's determination of the fair value of each reporting unit incorporates multiple inputs including discounted cash flow calculations, peer company price to earnings multiples, the level of the Company's Class A common stock price and assumptions that market participants would make in valuing the reporting unit.
24090_13_ITEM15_P66_S1	Other assumptions can include levels of economic capital, future business growth, and earnings projections.
24090_13_ITEM15_P67_S0	As of December 31, 2012 , the Company had goodwill of $12.6 million allocated to the Life Insurance segment and $4.5 million allocated to the Home Service Insurance segment.
24090_13_ITEM15_P67_S1	The Company completes its annual goodwill assessment for the individual reporting units within the Life Insurance segment and Home Service Insurance segment as of December 31 each year.
24090_13_ITEM15_P67_S2	There was no impairment of goodwill in 2012 , 2011 or 2010 .
24090_13_ITEM15_P68_S0	At December 31, 2012 and 2011 , participating business approximated 60.8% and 59.2% , respectively, of direct life insurance in force.
24090_13_ITEM15_P69_S0	Future policy benefits on participating policies are estimated based on net level premium reserves for death and endowment policy benefits ranging from 3% to 8% , and the cash surrender values described in such contracts.
24090_13_ITEM15_P70_S0	The scaling rate used for the 2012 portfolio ranged between 3.2% up to 4.0% over 3 years and then going up to 5% at 15 years and remaining there for the duration.
24090_13_ITEM15_P71_S0	Earnings and dividends on participating policies are allocated based on policies in force.
24090_13_ITEM15_P72_S0	Policyholder dividends are determined based on the discretion of the Board of Directors of the policy issuing subsidiary.
24090_13_ITEM15_P72_S1	Policyholder dividends are accrued over the premium paying periods of the insurance contract.
24090_13_ITEM15_P73_S0	Basic earnings per share are computed by dividing income available to common stockholders by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding during each period.
24090_13_ITEM15_P73_S1	Diluted earnings per share are computed under the if-converted method for convertible securities and the treasury stock method for warrants, giving effect to all potential dilutive common stock, including options, warrants and convertible/redeemable preferred stock.
24090_13_ITEM15_P73_S2	The basic and diluted earnings per share of Class B common stock are one half the earnings per share of the Class A common stock.

24090_13_ITEM15_P76_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the estimated future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases.
24090_13_ITEM15_P76_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered.
24090_13_ITEM15_P77_S0	A deferred tax asset is recorded only if a determination is made that it is more-likely-than-not that the tax treatment on which the deferred tax asset depends will be sustained in the event of an audit.
24090_13_ITEM15_P77_S1	These determinations inherently involve management's judgment.
24090_13_ITEM15_P77_S2	In addition, the Company must record a tax valuation allowance with respect to deferred tax assets if it is more-likely-than-not that the tax benefit will not be realized.
24090_13_ITEM15_P77_S3	This valuation allowance is in essence a contra account to the deferred tax asset.
24090_13_ITEM15_P77_S4	Management must determine the portion of the deferred tax asset and resulting tax benefit that may not be realized based upon judgment of expected outcomes.
24090_13_ITEM15_P78_S0	Due to significant estimates utilized in establishing the valuation allowance and the potential for changes in facts and circumstances, it is reasonably possible that we will be required to record adjustments to the valuation allowance in future reporting periods.
24090_13_ITEM15_P78_S1	Such a charge could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and capital position.

24090_13_ITEM15_P80_S0	We amortize leasehold improvements over the shorter of the related lease term or the estimated life of the improvements.
24090_13_ITEM15_P80_S1	The Company has no capital leases.
