24090_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following is management's discussion and analysis of the consolidated financial condition and consolidated results of operations of the Company.
24090_16_ITEM7_P0_S1	It is intended to be a discussion of certain key financial information regarding the Company and should be read in conjunction with the Consolidated Financial Statements and related Notes to this report on Form 10-K.
24090_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	We conduct operations as an insurance holding company emphasizing ordinary life insurance and endowment products in niche markets where we believe we can achieve competitive advantages.
24090_16_ITEM7_P1_S1	As an insurance provider, we collect premiums on an ongoing basis to pay future benefits to our policy and contract holders.
24090_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company derives its revenues principally from 1) premiums earned for insurance coverages provided to insureds; 2) net investment income; and 3) net realized capital gains and losses.
24090_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	Profitability of our insurance operations depends heavily upon the Company s underwriting discipline, as we seek to manage exposure to loss through favorable risk selection and diversification, management of claims, use of reinsurance, the size of our in force block, actual mortality and morbidity experience, and our ability to manage our expense ratio, which we accomplish through economies of scale and management of acquisition costs and other underwriting expenses.
24090_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	Pricing adequacy depends on a number of factors, including the ability to obtain regulatory approval for rate changes, proper evaluation of underwriting risks, the ability to project future losses based on historical loss experience adjusted for known trends, the Company s response to competitors, and expectations about regulatory and legal developments and expense levels.
24090_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	The Company seeks to price our insurance policies such that insurance premiums and future net investment income earned on premiums received will cover underwriting expenses and the ultimate cost of paying claims reported on the policies and provide for a profit margin.
24090_16_ITEM7_P5_S1	The profitability of fixed annuities, riders and other spread-based product features depends largely on the Company s ability to earn target spreads between earned investment rates on assets and interest credited to policyholders.
24090_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	The investment return, or yield, on invested assets is an important element of the Company s earnings since insurance products are priced with the assumption that premiums received can be invested for a period of time before benefits are paid.
24090_16_ITEM7_P6_S1	The majority of the Company s invested assets have been held in fixed maturities available-for-sale and held-to-maturity securities, primarily in asset classes of corporate bonds, municipal bonds, and government obligation bonds.
24090_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	The current and projected low interest rate environment is having a significant impact on the determination of insurance contract liabilities and assets regarding reserves and deferred acquisition costs.
24090_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	The primary investment objective for the Company is to maximize economic value, consistent with acceptable risk parameters, including the management of credit risk and interest rate sensitivity of invested assets, while generating sufficient after-tax income to meet policyholder and corporate obligations.
24090_16_ITEM7_P8_S1	The Company maintains a conservative investment strategy that may vary based on a variety of factors including business needs, regulatory requirements and tax considerations.
24090_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	In the first quarter of 2015, we determined that a portion of the life insurance policies issued by our subsidiary insurance companies failed to qualify for the favorable U.S. federal income tax treatment afforded by Sections 7702 of the Internal Revenue Code ("IRC") of 1986.
24090_16_ITEM7_P9_S1	As a result, we established a reserve as of December 31, 2014 of $11.4 million for probable liabilities and expenses associated with this tax compliance matter, which amount represented the low end of management s estimated range of those probable expenses and liabilities of $11.4 million to $40.0 million, net of tax.
24090_16_ITEM7_P9_S2	During 2015, we performed a by-policy calculation and have a best estimate as of December 31, 2015 of $12.6 million, after tax.
24090_16_ITEM7_P9_S3	In addition, we also booked a liability for IRC 72(s) failures related to annuity contracts of $2.5 million as of June 30, 2015.
24090_16_ITEM7_P9_S4	We have updated this liability based upon current information to $2.0 million as of December 31, 2015.
24090_16_ITEM7_P9_S5	These estimates include projected toll charges and fees payable to the IRS, as well as estimated increased payout obligations to current and former holders of non-compliant domestic life insurance policies expected to result from remediation of those policies.
24090_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	the number of domestic life insurance policies we will be required to remediate, and the methodology applicable to the calculation of taxable benefits under non-compliant policies.

24090_16_ITEM7_P24_S0	Significant economic issues impacting our business and industry currently and into the future are discussed below.
24090_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	Slow increases in the interest rate environment will limit increases in profit margins for insurers.
24090_16_ITEM7_P25_S1	We have been impacted by the historically low interest rate environment over the past several years as our fixed income investment portfolio, primarily invested in callable securities, has been reinvested at lower yields.
24090_16_ITEM7_P25_S2	The Company s conservative investment strategy has not changed but we have focused new purchases into holding of state, municipalities and essential service issuers compared to our historical investment in U.S. government holdings.
24090_16_ITEM7_P25_S3	Our investment earnings also impact the reserve and Deferred Acquisition Costs ( DAC ) balances, as assumptions are used in the development of the balances.
24090_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	Due to the recent decline in investment yields on our portfolio, our projection of long-term investment returns has declined.
24090_16_ITEM7_P26_S1	This has resulted in increasing the reserves on policies issued in the current year, as well as reducing the DAC asset.
24090_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	As an increasing percentage of the world population reaches retirement age, we believe we will benefit from increased demand for living benefit products rather than death products, as customers will require cash accumulation to pay expenses to meet their lifetime income needs.
24090_16_ITEM7_P27_S1	Our ordinary life products are designed to accumulate cash values to provide for living expenses in a policy owner's later years, while continuously providing a death benefit.
24090_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	We believe there is a trend toward consolidation of domestic life insurance companies, due to significant losses incurred by the life insurance industry as a result of the credit crisis and related economic pressures, as well as increasing costs of regulatory compliance for domestic life insurance companies.
24090_16_ITEM7_P28_S1	We believe this trend should benefit our acquisition strategy as more complementary acquisition candidates may become available for us to consider.
24090_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	Many of the events and trends affecting the life insurance industry have had an impact on the life reinsurance industry.
24090_16_ITEM7_P29_S1	These events have led to a decline in the availability of reinsurance.
24090_16_ITEM7_P29_S2	While we currently cede a limited amount of our primary insurance business to reinsurers, we may find it difficult to obtain reinsurance in the future, forcing us to seek reinsurers who are more expensive to us.
24090_16_ITEM7_P29_S3	If we cannot obtain affordable reinsurance coverage, either our net exposures will increase or we will have to reduce our underwriting commitments.
24090_16_ITEM7_P30_S0	While our management has extensive experience in writing life insurance policies for foreign residents, changes to foreign laws and regulations and their related application and enforcement, along with currency controls affecting our foreign resident insureds could adversely impact our revenues, results of operations and financial condition.
24090_16_ITEM7_P31_S0	On August 1, 2011, SPLIC entered into assumption reinsurance agreements with Escude Life Insurance Company in Rehabilitation, and Benton Life Insurance Company in Rehabilitation.
24090_16_ITEM7_P31_S1	At the time the agreements were executed, both companies were under receivership with the Louisiana Department of Insurance.
24090_16_ITEM7_P31_S2	In total, SPLIC assumed approximately $4.5 million in reserve liabilities and received approximately $4.6 million in cash, with a minimal reinsurance ceding commission being paid.
24090_16_ITEM7_P31_S3	These transactions are accounted for under business combination accounting and are not deemed material.

24090_16_ITEM7_P132_S0	We evaluate the carrying value of our fixed maturity and equity securities at least quarterly.
24090_16_ITEM7_P133_S0	The Company monitors all debt and equity securities on an on-going basis relative to changes in credit ratings, market prices, earnings trends and financial performance, in addition to specific region or industry reviews.
24090_16_ITEM7_P134_S0	The assessment of whether impairments have occurred is based on a case-by-case evaluation of underlying reasons for the decline in fair value.
24090_16_ITEM7_P135_S0	The Company determines other-than-temporary impairment ( OTTI ) by reviewing all relevant evidence related to the specific security issuer as well as the Company's intent to sell the security, or if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell a security before recovery of its amortized cost.
24090_16_ITEM7_P136_S0	When an OTTI has occurred, the amount of the OTTI recognized in earnings depends on whether the Company intends to sell the security or more likely than not will be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis.
24090_16_ITEM7_P136_S1	If the Company intends to sell the security or more likely than not will be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis, an OTTI is recognized in earnings equal to the entire difference between the investment's cost and its fair value at the balance sheet date.
24090_16_ITEM7_P136_S2	If the Company does not intend to sell the security and it is not more likely than not that the Company is required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis, the OTTI will be separated into the following: a) the amount representing the credit loss; and b) the amount related to all other factors.
24090_16_ITEM7_P136_S3	The amount of the total OTTI related to the credit loss is recognized in earnings.
24090_16_ITEM7_P136_S4	The amount of the total OTTI related to other factors is recognized in other comprehensive income, net of applicable taxes.
24090_16_ITEM7_P136_S5	The previous amortized cost basis less the OTTI recognized in earnings becomes the new amortized cost basis of the investment.
24090_16_ITEM7_P136_S6	The new amortized cost is not adjusted for subsequent recoveries in fair value.
24090_16_ITEM7_P137_S0	We recorded a write-down in 2015 related to impairments on two bond mutual funds totaling $2.4 million and impairments on two bond issuers totaling $3.0 million related to a utility and energy issuer.
24090_16_ITEM7_P137_S1	In 2014, impairments of $0.4 million were recorded as a result of our OTTI analysis.
24090_16_ITEM7_P137_S2	There were no OTTI impairments recorded during 2013.
24090_16_ITEM7_P137_S3	Based upon our analysis of whether declines in fair value below cost are temporary or other-than-temporary, management believes that our investments in fixed maturity investments at December 31, 2015 were not impaired, and no additional other-than-temporary losses need to be recorded.

24090_16_ITEM7_P139_S0	As is customary among insurance companies, our insurance company subsidiaries reinsure with other companies portions of the life insurance risks they underwrite.
24090_16_ITEM7_P139_S1	A primary purpose of reinsurance agreements is to enable an insurance company to reduce the amount of risk on any particular life and, by reinsuring the amount exceeding the maximum amount the insurance company is willing to retain, to insure individuals in amounts larger than it could without such agreements.
24090_16_ITEM7_P139_S2	Even though a portion of the risk may be reinsured, our insurance company subsidiaries remain liable to perform all the obligations imposed by the policies issued by them and could be liable if their reinsurers were unable to meet their obligations under the reinsurance agreements.
24090_16_ITEM7_P140_S0	We believe we have established appropriate reinsurance coverage based upon our net retained insured liabilities compared to our surplus.

24090_16_ITEM7_P142_S0	Our insurance subsidiaries monitor the solvency of their reinsurers in seeking to minimize the risk of loss in the event of default by a reinsurer.
24090_16_ITEM7_P143_S0	The primary reinsurers of our insurance subsidiaries are large, well-capitalized entities.

24090_16_ITEM7_P149_S0	Liquidity refers to a company's ability to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the needs of its operations.
24090_16_ITEM7_P149_S1	Liquidity is managed on insurance operations to ensure stable and reliable sources of cash flows to meet obligations and is provided by a variety of sources.
24090_16_ITEM7_P150_S0	Our liquidity requirements are met primarily by funds provided from operations.
24090_16_ITEM7_P150_S1	Premium deposits and revenues, investment income and investment maturities are the primary sources of funds, while investment purchases, policy benefits, and operating expenses are the primary uses of funds.
24090_16_ITEM7_P150_S2	We historically have not had to liquidate investments to provide cash flow, and there were no liquidity issues in 2015 or 2014 .
24090_16_ITEM7_P150_S3	Our investments consist of 67.6% of marketable debt securities and 2.2% of equity securities classified as available-for-sale that could be readily converted to cash for liquidity needs.
24090_16_ITEM7_P151_S0	A primary liquidity concern is the risk of an extraordinary level of early policyholder withdrawals.
24090_16_ITEM7_P151_S1	We include provisions within our insurance policies, such as surrender charges, that help limit and discourage early withdrawals.
24090_16_ITEM7_P151_S2	Since these contractual withdrawals, as well as the level of surrenders experienced, have been largely consistent with our assumptions in asset liability management, our associated cash outflows have, historically, not had an adverse impact on our overall liquidity.
24090_16_ITEM7_P152_S0	Individual life insurance policies are less susceptible to withdrawal than annuity reserves and deposit liabilities because policyholders may incur surrender charges and undergo a new underwriting process in order to obtain a new insurance policy.
24090_16_ITEM7_P152_S1	Cash flow projections and cash flow tests under various market interest rate scenarios are also performed annually to assist in evaluating liquidity needs and adequacy.
24090_16_ITEM7_P153_S0	We currently anticipate that available liquidity sources and future cash flows will be adequate to meet our needs for funds.
24090_16_ITEM7_P154_S0	Cash flows from our insurance operations historically have been sufficient to meet current needs.

24090_16_ITEM7_P156_S0	In 2015, we determined that a portion of the life insurance and annuity policies issued by our subsidiary insurance companies failed to qualify for the favorable U.S. federal income tax treatment afforded by Sections 7702 and 72(s) of the Internal Revenue Code ("IRC") of 1986.
24090_16_ITEM7_P156_S1	As a result, we have established a liability reserve of $ 14.6 million, net of tax for probable liabilities and expenses associated with this tax compliance matter, which represents management s estimate and we have disclosed an estimated range related to probable liabilities and expenses of $9.0 million to $45.5 million , net of tax.
24090_16_ITEM7_P156_S2	This estimate and range includes projected toll charges and fees payable to the IRS, as well as estimated increased payout obligations to current and former holders of non-compliant domestic life insurance policies expected to result from remediation of those policies.
24090_16_ITEM7_P156_S3	The amount of our liabilities and expenses depends on a number of uncertainties, including the number of prior tax years for which we may be liable to the IRS, the number of domestic life insurance policies we will be required to remediate, and the methodology applicable to the calculation of taxable benefits under non-compliant policies.
24090_16_ITEM7_P156_S4	Given the range of potential outcomes and the significant variables assumed in establishing our estimates, actual amounts incurred may exceed our reserve and also could exceed the high end of our estimated range of liabilities and expenses.
24090_16_ITEM7_P157_S0	This tax compliance issue impacts our policyholders and their tax liabilities relative to these products that fail 7702 and 72(s) for those that will not be remediated.
24090_16_ITEM7_P158_S0	The exposure related to future sales or products in force is unknown at this time.
24090_16_ITEM7_P159_S0	could decide to surrender their policies due to this issue which would subsequently result in higher cash outflows due to an increase in surrender activity.
24090_16_ITEM7_P160_S0	The NAIC has established minimum capital requirements in the form of RBC.
24090_16_ITEM7_P160_S1	RBC considers the type of business written by an insurance company, the quality of its assets, and various other aspects of an insurance company's business to develop a minimum level of capital called "Authorized Control Level Risk-based Capital" and compares this level to an adjusted statutory capital that includes capital and surplus as reported under statutory accounting principles, plus certain investment reserves.
24090_16_ITEM7_P160_S2	Should the ratio of adjusted statutory capital to control level risk-based capital fall below 200%, a series of remedial actions by the affected company would be required.
24090_16_ITEM7_P161_S0	At December 31, 2015 , all of our insurance subsidiaries were above the required minimum RBC levels.

24090_16_ITEM7_P171_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect reported amounts and related disclosures.
24090_16_ITEM7_P171_S1	Management considers an accounting estimate to be critical if: (1) it requires assumptions to be made that were uncertain at the time the estimate was made; and (2) changes in the estimate, or different estimates that could have been selected, could have a material effect on our consolidated results of operations or financial condition.
24090_16_ITEM7_P171_S2	While we believe that our estimates, assumptions and judgments are reasonable, they are based on information presently available.
24090_16_ITEM7_P171_S3	Additionally, changes in our assumptions, estimates or assessments as a result of unforeseen events or otherwise could have a material impact on our financial position or results of operations.
24090_16_ITEM7_P172_S0	Management has discussed the development and selection of its critical accounting estimates with the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors, and the Audit Committee has reviewed the disclosure presented below relating to them.
24090_16_ITEM7_P173_S0	No. 1, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies, of the Notes to our Financial Statements for further information on our critical accounting policies.
24090_16_ITEM7_P174_S0	Our critical accounting policies are as follows:
24090_16_ITEM7_P175_S0	Future policy benefit reserves have been computed by the net level premium method with assumptions as to investment yields, dividends on participating business, mortality and withdrawals based upon our experience.
24090_16_ITEM7_P175_S1	The preparation of financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of policy liabilities and the increase in future policy benefit reserves.
24090_16_ITEM7_P175_S2	Management's judgments and estimates for future policy benefit reserves provide for possible unfavorable deviation.
24090_16_ITEM7_P176_S0	We continue to use the original assumptions (including a provision for the risk of adverse deviation) in subsequent periods to determine the changes in the liability for future policy benefits (the "lock-in concept ) unless a premium deficiency exists.
24090_16_ITEM7_P176_S1	Management monitors these assumptions and has determined that a premium deficiency did not exist as of December 31, 2015 .
24090_16_ITEM7_P176_S2	Management believes that our policy liabilities and increase in future policy benefit reserves as of the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 are based upon assumptions, including a provision for the risk of adverse deviation, that do not warrant revision.
24090_16_ITEM7_P177_S0	Acquisition costs, consisting of commissions and policy issuance, underwriting and agency expenses that relate to and vary with the successful production of new business, are deferred.
24090_16_ITEM7_P177_S1	These deferred policy acquisition costs are amortized primarily over the estimated profits, using the same assumptions as were used in computing liabilities for future policy benefits.
24090_16_ITEM7_P178_S0	We utilize the factor method to determine the amount of costs to be capitalized and the ending asset balance.
24090_16_ITEM7_P178_S1	The factor method is based on the ratio of premium revenue recognized for the policies in force at the end of each reporting period compared to the premium revenue recognized for policies in force at the beginning of the reporting period.
24090_16_ITEM7_P178_S2	The factor method ensures that policies which lapsed or surrendered during the reporting period are no longer included in the deferred policy acquisition costs calculation.
24090_16_ITEM7_P178_S3	The factor method limits the amount of deferred costs to its estimated realizable value, provided actual experience is comparable to that contemplated in the factors.
24090_16_ITEM7_P179_S0	Inherent in the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs are certain management judgments about what acquisition costs are deferred, the ending asset balance and the annual amortization.
24090_16_ITEM7_P179_S1	Approximately 94.0% of our capitalized deferred acquisition costs are attributed to first year excess commissions.
24090_16_ITEM7_P179_S2	The remaining 6.0% are attributed to costs that vary with and are directly related to the successful acquisition of new insurance business.
24090_16_ITEM7_P179_S3	Those costs generally include costs related to the production, underwriting and issuance of new business.
24090_16_ITEM7_P180_S0	A recoverability test that considers, among other things, actual experience and projected future experience is performed at least annually.
24090_16_ITEM7_P180_S1	These annual recoverability tests initially calculate the available premium (gross premium less benefit and expense portion of premium) for the next 30 years.
24090_16_ITEM7_P180_S2	The available premium per policy and the deferred policy acquisition costs per policy are then calculated.
24090_16_ITEM7_P180_S3	The deferred policy acquisition costs are then evaluated over two methods utilizing reasonable assumptions and two other methods using pessimistic assumptions.
24090_16_ITEM7_P180_S4	The two methods using reasonable assumptions illustrate an early-deferred policy acquisition recoverability period.
24090_16_ITEM7_P180_S5	The two methods utilizing pessimistic assumptions still support early recoverability of our aggregate deferred policy acquisition costs.
24090_16_ITEM7_P181_S0	Management believes that our deferred policy acquisition costs and related amortization for the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 limits the amount of deferred costs to its estimated realizable value.
24090_16_ITEM7_P181_S1	This belief is based upon the analysis performed on capitalized expenses that vary with and are primarily related to the acquisition of new and renewal insurance business, utilization of the factor method and annual recoverability testing.
24090_16_ITEM7_P182_S0	Cost of Customer Relationships Acquired ("CCRA") is established when we purchase a block of insurance.
24090_16_ITEM7_P182_S1	CCRA is amortized primarily over the emerging profit of the related policies using the same assumptions as were used in computing liabilities for future policy benefits.
24090_16_ITEM7_P183_S0	We utilize various methods to determine the amount of the ending asset balance, including a static model and a dynamic model.
24090_16_ITEM7_P183_S1	Inherent in the amortization of CCRA are certain management judgments about the ending asset balance and the annual amortization.
24090_16_ITEM7_P183_S2	The assumptions used are based upon interest, mortality and lapses at the time of purchase.
24090_16_ITEM7_P184_S0	A recoverability test that considers, among other things, actual experience and projected future experience is performed at least annually.
24090_16_ITEM7_P184_S1	These annual recoverability tests initially calculate the available premium (gross premium less benefit and expense portion of premium) for the next thirty years.
24090_16_ITEM7_P184_S2	The CCRA is then evaluated utilizing reasonable assumptions.
24090_16_ITEM7_P184_S3	Management believes our CCRA and related amortization is recoverable for the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 .
24090_16_ITEM7_P184_S4	This belief is based upon the analysis performed on estimated future results of the block and our annual recoverability testing.
24090_16_ITEM7_P185_S0	Current accounting guidance requires that goodwill balances be reviewed for impairment at least annually or more frequently if events occur or circumstances change that would indicate that a triggering event has occurred.
24090_16_ITEM7_P186_S0	A reporting unit is defined as an operating segment on one level below an operating segment.
24090_16_ITEM7_P186_S1	Most of the Company's reporting units, for which goodwill has been allocated, are equivalent to the Company's operating segment, as there is no discrete financial information available for the separate components of the segment or all of the components of the segment have similar economic characteristics.
24090_16_ITEM7_P187_S0	The goodwill impairment test follows a multi-step process as defined under current accounting guidance.
24090_16_ITEM7_P187_S1	An initial review may be performed whereby the assessment is based upon qualitative factors before performing the first test step.
24090_16_ITEM7_P188_S0	In the first step, the fair value of a reporting unit is compared to its carrying value.
24090_16_ITEM7_P188_S1	If the carrying value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the impairment test is performed for purposes of measuring the impairment.
24090_16_ITEM7_P188_S2	In the second step, the fair value of the reporting unit is allocated to all of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit to determine an implied goodwill value.
24090_16_ITEM7_P189_S0	carrying amount of the reporting unit goodwill exceeds the implied goodwill value, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to that excess.
24090_16_ITEM7_P190_S0	Management's determination of the fair value of each reporting unit incorporates multiple inputs including discounted cash flow calculations, peer company price to earnings multiples, the level of the Company's Class A common stock price and assumptions that market participants would make in valuing the reporting unit.
24090_16_ITEM7_P190_S1	Other assumptions can include levels of economic capital, future business growth, and earnings projections.
24090_16_ITEM7_P191_S0	The evaluation of securities for impairments is a quantitative and qualitative process, which is subject to risks and uncertainties and is intended to determine whether declines in the fair value of investments should be recognized in current period earnings.
24090_16_ITEM7_P191_S1	The risks and uncertainties include changes in general economic conditions, the issuer's financial condition or future prospects, the effects of changes in interest rates or credit spreads and the expected recovery period.
24090_16_ITEM7_P192_S0	Based upon current accounting guidance, investment securities must be classified as held-to-maturity, available-for-sale or trading.
24090_16_ITEM7_P192_S1	Management determines the appropriate classification at the time of purchase.
24090_16_ITEM7_P193_S0	The classification of securities is significant since it directly impacts the accounting for unrealized gains and losses on securities.
24090_16_ITEM7_P193_S1	Fixed maturity securities are classified as held-to-maturity and carried at amortized cost when management has the positive intent and the Company has the ability to hold the securities to maturity.
24090_16_ITEM7_P193_S2	Securities not classified as held-to-maturity are classified as available-for-sale and are carried at fair value, with the unrealized holding gains and losses, net of tax, reported in other comprehensive income and do not affect earnings until realized.
24090_16_ITEM7_P194_S0	The Company evaluates all securities on a quarterly basis, and more frequently when economic conditions warrant additional evaluations, for determining if an OTTI exists pursuant to the accounting guidelines.
24090_16_ITEM7_P194_S1	In evaluating the possible impairment of securities, consideration is given to the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has been less than cost, the financial conditions and near-term prospects of the issuer, and the ability and intent of the Company to retain its investment in the issuer for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in fair value.
24090_16_ITEM7_P194_S2	In analyzing an issuer's financial condition, the Company may consider whether the securities are issued by the Federal government or its agencies, by government-sponsored agencies, or whether downgrades by bond rating agencies have occurred, and reviews of the issuer's financial condition.
24090_16_ITEM7_P195_S0	If management determines that an investment experienced an OTTI, management must then determine the amount of OTTI to be recognized in earnings.
24090_16_ITEM7_P195_S1	If management does not intend to sell the security and it is more likely than not that the Company will not be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period loss, the OTTI will be separated into the amount representing the credit loss and the amount related to all other factors.
24090_16_ITEM7_P195_S2	The amount of OTTI related to the credit loss is determined based on the present value of cash flows expected to be collected and is recognized in earnings.
24090_16_ITEM7_P195_S3	The amount of OTTI related to other factors will be recognized in other comprehensive income, net of applicable taxes.
24090_16_ITEM7_P195_S4	The previous amortized cost basis less the OTTI recognized in earnings will become the new amortized cost basis of the investment.
24090_16_ITEM7_P195_S5	If management intends to sell the security or more likely than not will be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period credit loss, the OTTI will be recognized in earnings equal to the entire difference between the investment's amortized cost basis and its fair value at the balance sheet date.
24090_16_ITEM7_P195_S6	Any recoveries related to the value of these securities are recorded as an unrealized gain (as other comprehensive income (loss) in shareholders' equity) and not recognized in income until the security is ultimately sold.
24090_16_ITEM7_P196_S0	The Company from time to time may dispose of an impaired security in response to asset/liability management decisions, future market movements, business plan changes, or if the net proceeds can be reinvested at a rate of return that is expected to recover the loss within a reasonable period of time.
24090_16_ITEM7_P197_S0	Premiums on life and accident and health policies are reported as earned when due or, for short duration contracts, over the contract period on a pro rata basis.
24090_16_ITEM7_P197_S1	Benefits and expenses are associated with earned premiums so as to result in recognition of profits over the estimated life of the contracts.
24090_16_ITEM7_P197_S2	This matching is accomplished by means of provisions for future benefits and the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs.
24090_16_ITEM7_P198_S0	Annuities are accounted for in a manner consistent with accounting for interest bearing financial instruments.
24090_16_ITEM7_P199_S0	Our primary annuity products do not include fees or other such charges.
24090_16_ITEM7_P200_S0	A deferred tax asset or deferred tax liability is recorded only if a determination is made that it is more-likely-than-not that the tax treatment on which the deferred tax item depends will be sustained in the event of an audit.
24090_16_ITEM7_P200_S1	These determinations inherently involve management's judgment.
24090_16_ITEM7_P200_S2	In addition, the Company must record a tax valuation allowance with respect to deferred tax assets if it is more-likely-than-not that the tax benefit will not be realized.
24090_16_ITEM7_P200_S3	This valuation allowance is in essence a contra account to the deferred tax asset.
24090_16_ITEM7_P200_S4	Management must determine the portion of the deferred tax asset and resulting tax benefit that may not be realized based upon judgment of expected outcomes.
24090_16_ITEM7_P201_S0	Due to significant estimates utilized in establishing the valuation allowance and the potential for changes in facts and circumstances, it is reasonably possible that we will be required to record a valuation allowance in future reporting periods.
24090_16_ITEM7_P201_S1	Such a charge could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and capital position.
24090_16_ITEM7_P202_S0	An estimated loss from a contingency is accrued and charged to results of operations only if both of the following conditions are met:
24090_16_ITEM7_P203_S0	Information available prior to the issuance of the financial statements indicates that it is probable (virtual certainty is not required) that an asset has been impaired or a liability incurred as of the date of the financial statements; and 2.
24090_16_ITEM7_P203_S1	The amount of the loss can be reasonably estimated.
24090_16_ITEM7_P204_S0	Reasonable estimation of a possible loss does not require estimating a single amount of the loss.
24090_16_ITEM7_P204_S1	It requires that a loss be accrued if it can be estimated within a range.
24090_16_ITEM7_P204_S2	If an amount within the range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, that amount is accrued.
24090_16_ITEM7_P204_S3	If no amount within the range is a better estimate than any other amount, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.
24090_16_ITEM7_P205_S0	A gain contingency is an uncertain situation that will be resolved in the future, possibly resulting in a gain.
24090_16_ITEM7_P205_S1	We do not allow the recognition of a gain contingency prior to settlement of the underlying event.
24090_16_ITEM7_P205_S2	If we were to have a gain contingency, we would disclose it in the notes to the financial statements.
24090_16_ITEM7_P206_S0	Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, Note 1.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The nature of our business exposes us to market risk relative to our invested assets and policy liabilities.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Market risk is the risk of loss that may occur when changes in interest rates and public equity prices adversely affect the value of our invested assets.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Interest rate risk is our primary market risk exposure.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P0_S3	Substantial and sustained increases and decreases in market interest rates can affect the fair value of our investments.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P0_S4	The fair value of our fixed maturity portfolio generally increases when interest rates decrease and decreases when interest rates increase.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The following table summarizes net unrealized gains and losses as of the dates indicated.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Our exposure to interest rate changes results from our significant holdings of fixed maturity investments, policy loans and mortgage loans on real estate, all of which comprised over 90.2% of our cash and investment portfolio as of December 31, 2015 .
24090_16_ITEM7A_P2_S1	These investments are mainly exposed to changes in U.S. Treasury rates.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Our fixed maturities investments include U.S. Government-sponsored enterprises, U.S. Government bonds, securities issued by government agencies, state and municipal bonds, and corporate bonds.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Approximately 72.5% of the fixed maturities we owned at market value on December 31, 2015 are state and political subdivisions which are primarily municipal holdings.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P2_S4	These holdings are diversified over several states.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Changes in interest rates typically have a sizable effect on the fair value of our debt and equities securities.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The interest rate of the ten-year U.S. Treasury bond increased to 2.27% during the year ended 2015, from 2.17% at December 31, 2014 .
24090_16_ITEM7A_P3_S2	Net unrealized gains on fixed maturity securities totaled $26.5 million at December 31, 2015, compared to $47.2 million at December 31, 2014.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P4_S0	To manage interest risk, we perform periodic projections of asset and liability cash flows to evaluate the potential sensitivity of our investments and liabilities.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P5_S0	We assess interest rate sensitivity on an annual basis with respect to our fixed maturities investments using hypothetical test scenarios that assume either upward or downward shifts in the prevailing interest rates.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The Company performed an analysis of fair value changes using assumed 100 basis point upward shifts in interest rates, noting that the fair value of our fixed maturity investment portfolio of $1.0 billion would decrease approximately $50.2 million to a fair value of $950.4 million upon a 100 basis point increase.

24090_16_ITEM7A_P6_S0	While the test scenarios are for illustrative purposes only and do not reflect our expectations regarding future interest rates or the performance of fixed-income markets, it is a near-term change that illustrates the potential impact of such events.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P7_S0	Due to the composition of our book of insurance business, we believe it is unlikely we would encounter large surrender activity due to an interest rate increase that would force us to dispose of our fixed maturities at a loss.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P8_S0	Our fixed maturity portfolio is exposed to call risk as a significant portion of the current holdings are callable.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P8_S1	A decreasing interest rate environment can result in increased call activity as experienced over the past several years, and an increasing rate environment will likely result in securities being paid at their stated maturity.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P9_S0	There are no fixed maturities or other investments that we classify as trading instruments.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P9_S1	Approximately 73.5% of fixed maturities were held in available-for-sale and 26.5% in held-to-maturity based upon fair value at December 31, 2015 .
24090_16_ITEM7A_P9_S2	At December 31, 2015 and 2014 , we had no investments in derivative instruments, subprime loans or CDOs (collateralized debt obligations).
24090_16_ITEM7A_P10_S0	Changes in the level or volatility of equity prices affect the value of equity securities we hold as investments.
24090_16_ITEM7A_P10_S1	Our equity investments portfolio represented 2.2% of our total investments at December 31, 2015 , with 91.9% invested in diversified equity and bond mutual funds.

24090_16_ITEM9A_P0_S0	We have established disclosure controls and procedures to ensure, among other things, material information relating to our Company, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to our officers who certify our financial reports and to the other members of our senior management and the Board of Directors.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our Chief Executive Officer ("CEO") and our Chief Financial Officer ("CFO") are responsible for establishing and maintaining our disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the "Exchange Act")).
24090_16_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Based upon an evaluation at the end of the period, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that, in light of the material weakness described below, our disclosure controls and procedures were not effective as of the end of the period covered by this annual report.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Management of our Company is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Management assessed internal control over financial reporting based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission 2013 Framework ("COSO").
24090_16_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Based on that assessment, management has concluded that our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015 was not effective due to the material weakness described below.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P3_S0	As of December 31, 2015, we became aware of an ineffective management review control as it pertains to our tax review of external tax experts complex documentation.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Specifically, this documentation included the tax rollforward schedule that reconciles deferred taxes, uncertain tax position computations, life/non-life qualification tests and overall income tax expense recorded in the financial statements of the Company, all of which had some added complexity due to our IRC 7702 and 72(s) tax compliance issues.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P3_S2	Although there is increased complexity of the tax documentation, management is responsible for the accuracy of the financial statements.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P3_S3	Because of this ineffective management review control, there was a reasonable possibility that the Company s annual financial statements would have been filed containing a material misstatement.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P3_S4	Management concludes there is a material weakness in this management review control.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P3_S5	Management has begun documenting its remediation steps and strategy.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Our independent registered public accounting firm, Ernst Young LLP, has issued an attestation report on our internal control over financial reporting.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P4_S1	The report is included in item 9A(c) of this annual report.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P5_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Shareholders of Citizens, Inc. and subsidiaries: We have audited Citizens, Inc. and subsidiaries internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013 framework) (the COSO criteria).
24090_16_ITEM9A_P5_S1	Citizens, Inc. and subsidiaries management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting .
24090_16_ITEM9A_P5_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P6_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
24090_16_ITEM9A_P6_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P6_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P6_S3	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P7_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P7_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P8_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P8_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P9_S0	A material weakness is a deficiency, or combination of deficiencies, in internal control over financial reporting, such that there is a reasonable possibility that a material misstatement of the company s annual or interim financial statements will not be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P10_S0	provision and related current payable and deferred income tax balances.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P10_S1	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the 2015 consolidated financial statements.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P10_S2	This material weakness was considered in determining the nature, timing and extent of audit tests applied in our audit of the 2015 financial statements, and this report does not affect our report dated March 24, 2016 , which expressed an unqualified opinion on those financial statements.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P11_S0	In our opinion, because of the effect of the material weakness described above on the achievement of the objectives of the control criteria, Citizens, Inc. and subsidiaries has not maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on the COSO criteria.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P12_S0	As previously discussed, as of December 31, 2015, management detected an ineffective management review control as it pertains to our tax review of external tax experts complex documentation.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P12_S1	This has resulted in a change in internal control over financial reporting during the current period.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P12_S2	The Company did not have adequately designed and documented management review controls over the third party prepared tax documentation.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P12_S3	Specifically, the management review controls did not adequately address management s expectations, criteria for investigation, and the level of precision used in the performance of the review controls, resulting in a material weakness in internal controls over financial reporting.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P12_S4	Management has begun documenting its remediation steps and strategy.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P13_S0	As reported as of December 31, 2014, management became aware of an ineffective executive management review control as it pertains to our actuarial function that was relied upon by management.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P13_S1	Due to the nature of the failure, management believed this was an entity level control failure related to personnel competency and a lack of appropriate sensitivity and precision in executive management s review of the actuarial function.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P14_S0	The material weakness related to the sensitivity and precision of management s review control over the actuarial function is assessed by management to have been fully remediated as of December 31, 2015.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P15_S0	Remediation of the material weakness identified deficiency related to personnel competency in the actuarial function is assessed by management to be ongoing as of December 31, 2015.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P15_S1	However, in consideration of the changes and enhancements made to actuarial staff and support and the effective entity level controls, management does not believe that there is a reasonable possibility that a material misstatement of the Company's annual or interim financial statements will not be prevented or detected on a timely basis related to this deficiency.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P15_S2	Therefore management assesses the identified deficiency related to personnel competency in the actuarial function as a significant deficiency, which is a deficiency, or a combination of deficiencies, in internal control over financial reporting, that is less severe than a material weakness yet important enough to merit attention by those responsible for oversight of the Company's financial reporting.
24090_16_ITEM9A_P16_S0	There were no other changes in the Company s internal control over financial reporting during the fourth quarter of 2015 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company s internal control over financial reporting.

24090_16_ITEM15_P22_S0	The classification of securities is significant since it directly impacts the accounting for unrealized gains and losses on securities.
24090_16_ITEM15_P22_S1	Fixed maturity securities are classified as held-to-maturity and carried at amortized cost when management has the positive intent and the Company has the ability to hold the securities to maturity.
24090_16_ITEM15_P22_S2	Securities not classified as held-to-maturity are classified as available-for-sale and are carried at fair value, with the unrealized holding gains and losses, net of tax, reported in other comprehensive income and do not affect earnings until realized.
24090_16_ITEM15_P23_S0	Fixed maturities consist primarily of bonds classified as available-for-sale or held-to-maturity.
24090_16_ITEM15_P23_S1	The Company does not classify any fixed maturities as trading.
24090_16_ITEM15_P23_S2	Equity securities (including non-redeemable preferred stock) are considered available-for-sale and are reported at fair value.
24090_16_ITEM15_P24_S0	Unrealized gain (loss) of equity securities and fixed maturities held as available-for-sale is shown as a separate component of stockholders' equity, net of tax, and is a separate component of comprehensive income.
24090_16_ITEM15_P25_S0	The Company evaluates all securities on a quarterly basis, and more frequently when economic conditions warrant additional evaluations, for determining if an other-than-temporary impairment ("OTTI") exists pursuant to the accounting guidelines.
24090_16_ITEM15_P25_S1	In evaluating the possible impairment of securities, consideration is given to the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has been less than cost, the financial conditions and near-term prospects of the issuer, and the ability and intent of the Company to retain its investment in the issuer for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in fair value.
24090_16_ITEM15_P25_S2	In analyzing an issuer s financial condition, the Company may consider whether the securities are issued by the Federal government or its agencies, by government-sponsored agencies, or whether downgrades by bond rating agencies have occurred, and reviews of the issuer s financial condition.
24090_16_ITEM15_P26_S0	If management determines that an investment experienced an OTTI, management must then determine the amount of OTTI to be recognized in earnings.
24090_16_ITEM15_P26_S1	If management does not intend to sell the security and it is more likely than not that the Company will not be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period loss, the OTTI will be separated into the amount representing the credit loss and the amount related to all other factors.
24090_16_ITEM15_P26_S2	The amount of OTTI related to the credit loss is determined based on the present value of cash flows expected to be collected and is recognized in earnings.
24090_16_ITEM15_P26_S3	The amount of OTTI related to other factors will be recognized in other comprehensive income, net of applicable taxes.
24090_16_ITEM15_P26_S4	The previous amortized cost basis less the OTTI recognized in earnings will become the new amortized cost basis of the investment.
24090_16_ITEM15_P26_S5	If management intends to sell the security or more likely than not will be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period credit loss, the OTTI will be recognized in earnings equal to the entire difference between the investment's amortized cost basis and its fair value at the balance sheet date.
24090_16_ITEM15_P26_S6	Any recoveries related to the value of these securities are recorded as an unrealized gain (as other comprehensive income (loss) in stockholders' equity) and not recognized in income until the security is ultimately sold.
24090_16_ITEM15_P27_S0	The Company from time to time may dispose of an impaired security in response to asset/liability management decisions, future market movements, business plan changes, or if the net proceeds can be reinvested at a rate of return that is expected to recover the loss within a reasonable period of time.
24090_16_ITEM15_P28_S0	Mortgage loans on real estate and policy loans are reported at unpaid principal balances.
24090_16_ITEM15_P29_S0	Real estate and other long-term investments consist primarily of land and buildings that are recorded at depreciated cost.
24090_16_ITEM15_P29_S1	If the fair value of the real estate is less than the carrying value, an impairment loss is recognized and charged to earnings.
24090_16_ITEM15_P30_S0	Premiums and discounts are amortized or accreted over the life of the related security as an adjustment to yield using the effective interest method.
24090_16_ITEM15_P31_S0	Dividend and interest income is recognized when earned.
24090_16_ITEM15_P31_S1	Realized gains and losses are included in earnings and are derived using the specific identification method for determining the cost of securities sold.

24090_16_ITEM15_P33_S0	Premiums on life policies are recognized as earned when due.
24090_16_ITEM15_P33_S1	Due premiums on the balance sheet are net of allowances.
24090_16_ITEM15_P34_S0	Accident and health policies are recognized as revenue over the contract period on a pro rata basis.
24090_16_ITEM15_P34_S1	Benefits and expenses are associated with earned premiums so as to result in the recognition of profits over the estimated lives of the contracts.
24090_16_ITEM15_P34_S2	This matching is accomplished by means of a provision for future policy benefits and the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs.
24090_16_ITEM15_P35_S0	Annuity policies, primarily flexible premium fixed annuity products, are accounted for in a manner consistent with accounting for interest bearing financial instruments.

24090_16_ITEM15_P35_S2	The annuity products issued do not include fees or other such charges.
24090_16_ITEM15_P36_S0	Acquisition costs, consisting of commissions and policy issuance, underwriting and agent convention expenses that are primarily related to and vary with the successful production of new and renewal business have been deferred.
24090_16_ITEM15_P36_S1	These deferred amounts, referred to as deferred policy acquisition costs ("DAC"), are recorded as an asset on the balance sheet and amortized to income in a systematic manner, based on related contract revenues or gross profits as appropriate.
24090_16_ITEM15_P37_S0	Traditional life insurance and accident and health insurance acquisition costs are being amortized over the premium-paying period of the related policies using assumptions consistent with those used in computing future policy benefit liabilities.
24090_16_ITEM15_P37_S1	For universal life type contracts and investment contracts that include significant surrender charges or that yield significant revenues from sources other than the investment contract holders' funds, the deferred contract acquisition cost amortization is matched to the recognition of gross profit.
24090_16_ITEM15_P37_S2	The effect on the DAC asset that would result from realization of unrealized gains or losses is recognized with an offset to accumulated other comprehensive income in consolidated stockholders' equity.
24090_16_ITEM15_P38_S0	substantially changes a contract as defined in current accounting guidance, then the DAC is written off immediately through income and any new deferrable costs associated with the new replacement are deferred.
24090_16_ITEM15_P38_S1	If a contract modification does not substantially change the contract, the DAC amortization on the original contract will continue and any acquisition costs associated with the related modification are immediately expensed.
24090_16_ITEM15_P39_S0	We utilize the factor method to determine the amount of costs to be capitalized and the ending asset balance.
24090_16_ITEM15_P39_S1	The factor method is based on the ratio of premium revenue recognized for the policies in force at the end of each reporting period compared to the premium revenue recognized for policies in force at the beginning of the reporting period.
24090_16_ITEM15_P39_S2	The factor method ensures that policies lapsed or surrendered during the reporting period are no longer included in the deferred policy acquisition costs calculation.
24090_16_ITEM15_P39_S3	The factor method limits the amount of deferred costs to its estimated realizable value, provided actual experience is comparable to that contemplated in the factors.
24090_16_ITEM15_P40_S0	Inherent in the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs are certain management judgments about what acquisition costs are deferred, the ending asset balance and the annual amortization.
24090_16_ITEM15_P40_S1	Approximately 94% of our capitalized deferred acquisition costs are attributed to first year and renewal excess commissions.
24090_16_ITEM15_P40_S2	The remaining 6% are attributed to costs that vary with and are directly related to the successful acquisition of new insurance business.
24090_16_ITEM15_P40_S3	Those costs generally include costs related to the production, underwriting and issuance of new business.

24090_16_ITEM15_P41_S1	These annual recoverability tests initially calculate the available premium (gross premium less the benefit and expense portion of premium) for the next 30 years.
24090_16_ITEM15_P41_S2	The available premium per policy and the deferred policy acquisition costs per policy are then calculated.
24090_16_ITEM15_P41_S3	The deferred policy acquisition costs are then evaluated over two methods utilizing reasonable assumptions and two other methods using pessimistic assumptions.

24090_16_ITEM15_P57_S0	Goodwill is the difference between the purchase price in a business combination and the fair value of assets and liabilities acquired, and is not amortized.
24090_16_ITEM15_P57_S1	Other intangible assets include various state insurance licenses, which have been determined to have indefinite useful lives and, therefore, are not amortized.
24090_16_ITEM15_P57_S2	Both goodwill and other intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are subject to annual impairment analyzes.
24090_16_ITEM15_P58_S0	The goodwill impairment test uses a two-step process as set forth under current accounting guidance.
24090_16_ITEM15_P58_S1	In the first step, the fair value of a reporting unit is compared to its carrying value.
24090_16_ITEM15_P58_S2	If the carrying value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the impairment test is performed for purposes of measuring the impairment.
24090_16_ITEM15_P58_S3	In the second step, the fair value of the reporting unit is allocated to all of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit to determine an implied goodwill value.
24090_16_ITEM15_P58_S4	If the carrying amount of the reporting unit goodwill exceeds the implied goodwill value, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to that excess.
24090_16_ITEM15_P59_S0	Management's determination of the fair value of each reporting unit incorporates multiple inputs including discounted cash flow calculations, the level of the Company's Class A common stock price and assumptions that market participants would make in valuing the reporting unit.
24090_16_ITEM15_P59_S1	Other assumptions can include levels of economic capital, future business growth, and earnings projections.

24090_16_ITEM15_P68_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the estimated future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases.
24090_16_ITEM15_P68_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered.
24090_16_ITEM15_P69_S0	A deferred tax asset is recorded only if a determination is made that it is more-likely-than-not that the tax treatment on which the deferred tax asset depends will be sustained in the event of an audit.
24090_16_ITEM15_P69_S1	These determinations inherently involve management's judgment.
24090_16_ITEM15_P69_S2	In addition, the Company must record a tax valuation allowance with respect to deferred tax assets if it is more-likely-than-not that the tax benefit will not be realized.
24090_16_ITEM15_P69_S3	This valuation allowance is in essence a contra account to the deferred tax asset.
24090_16_ITEM15_P69_S4	Management must determine the portion of the deferred tax asset and resulting tax benefit that may not be realized based upon judgment of expected outcomes.

24090_16_ITEM15_P76_S0	An estimated loss from a contingency is accrued and charged to results of operations only if both of the following conditions are met:
24090_16_ITEM15_P77_S0	Information available prior to the issuance of the financial statements indicates that it is probable (virtual certainty is not required) that an asset has been impaired or a liability incurred as of the date of the financial statements; and 2.
24090_16_ITEM15_P77_S1	The amount of the loss can be reasonably estimated.
24090_16_ITEM15_P78_S0	Reasonable estimation of a possible loss does not require estimating a single amount of the loss.
24090_16_ITEM15_P78_S1	It requires that a loss be accrued if it can be estimated within a range.
24090_16_ITEM15_P78_S2	If an amount within the range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, that amount is accrued.
24090_16_ITEM15_P78_S3	If no amount within the range is a better estimate than any other amount, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.
24090_16_ITEM15_P79_S0	A gain contingency is an uncertain situation that will be resolved in the future, possibly resulting in a gain.
24090_16_ITEM15_P79_S1	We do not allow the recognition of a gain contingency prior to settlement of the underlying event.
24090_16_ITEM15_P79_S2	If we were to have a gain contingency, we would disclose it in the notes to the financial statements.

24090_16_ITEM15_P84_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued ASU No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606), which supersedes the revenue recognition requirements in ASC 605, Revenue Recognition.
24090_16_ITEM15_P84_S1	The core principle of ASU 2014-09 is that an entity should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
24090_16_ITEM15_P84_S2	The guidance provides a five-step process to achieve that core principle.
24090_16_ITEM15_P85_S0	ASU 2014-09 requires disclosures enabling users of financial statements to understand the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers.
24090_16_ITEM15_P85_S1	Additionally, qualitative and quantitative disclosures are required about contracts with customers, significant judgments and changes in judgments, and assets recognized from the costs to obtain or fulfill a contract.
24090_16_ITEM15_P86_S0	ASU 2014-09 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period, using one of two retrospective application methods.
24090_16_ITEM15_P86_S1	The Company is currently evaluating the effect that the adoption of this ASU will have on its financial statements.

24090_16_ITEM15_P110_S0	Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
24090_16_ITEM15_P110_S1	We hold fixed maturity and equity securities that are carried at fair value.
24090_16_ITEM15_P111_S0	Fair value measurements are generally based upon observable and unobservable inputs.
24090_16_ITEM15_P111_S1	Observable inputs reflect market data obtained from independent sources, while unobservable inputs reflect our view of market assumptions in the absence of observable market information.
24090_16_ITEM15_P111_S2	We utilize valuation techniques that maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs.
24090_16_ITEM15_P112_S0	All assets and liabilities carried at fair value are required to be classified and disclosed in one of the following three categories:
24090_16_ITEM15_P113_S0	Level 1 - Quoted prices for identical instruments in active markets.
24090_16_ITEM15_P114_S0	Level 2 - Quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets; quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active and model-derived valuations whose inputs or whose significant value drivers are observable.
24090_16_ITEM15_P115_S0	Level 3 - Instruments whose significant value drivers are unobservable.
24090_16_ITEM15_P116_S0	Level 1 primarily consists of financial instruments whose value is based on quoted market prices such as U.S. Treasury securities, publicly traded mutual fund investments and individual stocks.
24090_16_ITEM15_P117_S0	Level 2 includes those financial instruments that are valued by independent pricing services or broker quotes.
24090_16_ITEM15_P117_S1	These models are primarily industry-standard models that consider various inputs, such as interest rates, credit spreads and foreign exchange rates for the underlying financial instruments.
24090_16_ITEM15_P117_S2	All significant inputs are observable, or derived from observable information in the marketplace or are supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
24090_16_ITEM15_P118_S0	Financial instruments in this category primarily include corporate fixed maturity securities, U.S. Government-sponsored enterprise securities, municipal securities and certain mortgage and asset-backed securities.
24090_16_ITEM15_P119_S0	Level 3 is comprised of financial instruments whose fair value is estimated based on non-binding broker prices utilizing significant inputs not based on, or corroborated by, readily available market information.
24090_16_ITEM15_P119_S1	This category consists of two private placement mortgage-backed securities where we cannot corroborate the significant valuation inputs with market observable data.
24090_16_ITEM15_P120_S0	The following table sets forth our assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value on a recurring basis as of the date indicated.
24090_16_ITEM15_P121_S0	At December 31, 2015 , the fixed maturities, valued using a third-party pricing source, totaled $722.9 million for Level 2 assets and comprised 95.2% of total reported fair value.
24090_16_ITEM15_P121_S1	Fair values for Level 3 assets are based upon unadjusted broker quotes that are non-binding.
24090_16_ITEM15_P122_S0	The Level 1 and Level 2 valuations are reviewed and validated quarterly through random testing by comparisons to separate pricing models, other third party pricing services, and back tested to recent trades.
24090_16_ITEM15_P122_S1	In addition, we obtain information relative to the third party pricing models and review model parameters for reasonableness.
24090_16_ITEM15_P122_S2	For the period ended December 31, 2015 , there were no material changes to the valuation methods or assumptions used to determine fair values, and no broker or third party prices were changed from the values received.
24090_16_ITEM15_P123_S0	There were no transfers made between level 1 and 2 securities at December 31, 2015 or 2014 .
24090_16_ITEM15_P124_S0	Fair values of these securities are based upon quoted market price and are classified as Level 1 assets.

24090_16_ITEM15_P127_S1	Such reclassifications, if any, are reported as transfers in and out of Level 3 at the beginning fair value for the reporting period in which the changes occur.
24090_16_ITEM15_P128_S0	Estimates of fair values are made at a specific point in time, based on relevant market prices and information about the financial instrument.
24090_16_ITEM15_P128_S1	The estimated fair values of financial instruments presented below are not necessarily indicative of the amounts the Company might realize in actual market transactions.

24090_16_ITEM15_P152_S0	As of December 31, 2014, we determined that a portion of the life insurance policies issued by our subsidiary insurance companies failed to qualify for the favorable U.S. federal income tax treatment afforded by Sections 7702 of the Internal Revenue Code ("IRC") of 1986.
24090_16_ITEM15_P152_S1	This tax code section allows for qualifying products sold to clients to have favorable tax treatment such as the products inside build up is not taxable.
24090_16_ITEM15_P152_S2	By identifying certain products that we have sold with the intention of this favorable tax treatment but in fact they do not qualify under the IRC rules, our policyholders and CICA may now be subject to additional tax liabilities.
24090_16_ITEM15_P153_S0	The policies at issue were sold most substantially to non-U.S. citizens residing abroad and to a lesser extent domestically.
24090_16_ITEM15_P153_S1	Based upon a review of the options available to the Company we have determined we will not remediate our endowments and endowment-like products under IRC 7702 we have sold to non-U.S. citizens.
24090_16_ITEM15_P153_S2	We do intend to remediate the domestic products we have sold to U.S. citizens.
24090_16_ITEM15_P153_S3	In addition, as part of our continuing review we determined in July of 2015 certain annuity contracts do not contain qualifying language under IRC 72(s) as intended that would have provided for favorable tax treatment of the annuities.
24090_16_ITEM15_P153_S4	This issue affects both our domestic and international contract holders.

24090_17_ITEM1_P0_S0	Citizens, Inc. ( Citizens or the "Company") is an insurance holding company incorporated in Colorado serving the life insurance needs of individuals in the United States since 1969 and internationally since 1975.
24090_17_ITEM1_P0_S1	Through our insurance subsidiaries, we pursue a strategy of offering traditional insurance products in niche markets where we believe we are able to achieve competitive advantages.
24090_17_ITEM1_P0_S2	We had approximately $1.6 billion of assets at December 31, 2016 and approximately $4.5 billion of insurance in force.
24090_17_ITEM1_P0_S3	Our core insurance operations include issuing and servicing:
24090_17_ITEM1_P1_S0	final expense and limited liability property policies to middle and lower income households in Louisiana, Mississippi and Arkansas through employee and independent agents in our home service distribution channel and funeral homes.
24090_17_ITEM1_P2_S0	We were formed in 1969 by our founder, Harold E. Riley.
24090_17_ITEM1_P2_S1	Prior to our formation, Mr. Riley had many years of experience in the international and domestic life insurance business.
24090_17_ITEM1_P3_S0	Historically, our Company has experienced growth through acquisitions in the domestic market and through organic market expansion in the international market.
24090_17_ITEM1_P3_S1	We strive to generate bottom line returns using knowledge of our niche markets and our well-established distribution channels.
24090_17_ITEM1_P4_S0	Our business has grown, both internationally and domestically, in recent years, though our profitability has declined.
24090_17_ITEM1_P4_S1	From 2012 through 2016 , revenues rose 21% from $202.8 million in 2012 to $245.4 million in 2016 .
24090_17_ITEM1_P4_S2	During that same period, our assets grew 35% from $1,171.8 million to $1,583.7 million .
24090_17_ITEM1_P4_S3	During this same period, our net income declined 61% from $4.9 million to $2.0 million , primarily as a result of other than temporary impairments ("OTTI"), expense related to an additional tax liability contingency and higher consulting and legal costs as we proactively addressed the tax liability contingency and undertook an assessment of our business model and strategies.
