24090_18_ITEM7_P169_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with U.S. GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect reported amounts and related disclosures.
24090_18_ITEM7_P169_S1	Management considers an accounting estimate to be critical if: (1) it requires assumptions to be made that were uncertain at the time the estimate was made; and (2) changes in the estimate, or different estimates that could have been selected, could have a material effect on our consolidated results of operations or financial condition.
24090_18_ITEM7_P169_S2	While we believe that our estimates, assumptions and judgments are reasonable, they are based on information presently available.
24090_18_ITEM7_P169_S3	Additionally, changes in our assumptions, estimates or assessments as a result of unforeseen events or otherwise could have a material impact on our financial position or results of operations.
24090_18_ITEM7_P170_S0	Management has discussed the development and selection of its critical accounting estimates with the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors, and the Audit Committee has reviewed the disclosure presented below relating to them.
24090_18_ITEM7_P170_S1	See Note 1 - Summary of Significant Accounting Policies of the Company's consolidated financial statements for further information on our critical accounting policies.
24090_18_ITEM7_P171_S0	Our critical accounting policies are as follows:
24090_18_ITEM7_P172_S0	Future policy benefit reserves have been computed by the net level premium method with assumptions as to investment yields, dividends on participating business, mortality and withdrawals based upon our experience.
24090_18_ITEM7_P172_S1	The preparation of financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of policy liabilities and the increase in future policy benefit reserves.
24090_18_ITEM7_P172_S2	Management's judgments and estimates for future policy benefit reserves provide for possible unfavorable deviation.
24090_18_ITEM7_P173_S0	We continue to use the original assumptions (including a provision for the risk of adverse deviation) in subsequent periods to determine the changes in the liability for future policy benefits (the "lock-in concept ) unless a premium deficiency exists.
24090_18_ITEM7_P173_S1	Management monitors these assumptions and has determined that a premium deficiency did not exist as of December 31, 2017 .
24090_18_ITEM7_P173_S2	Management believes that our policy liabilities and increase in future policy benefit reserves as of the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 are based upon assumptions, including a provision for the risk of adverse deviation, that do not warrant revision.
24090_18_ITEM7_P174_S0	Acquisition costs, consisting of commissions and policy issuance, underwriting and agency expenses that relate to and vary with the successful production of new business, are deferred.
24090_18_ITEM7_P174_S1	These deferred policy acquisition costs are amortized primarily over the premium-paying period of the policies, using the same assumptions as were used in computing liabilities for future policy benefits.
24090_18_ITEM7_P175_S0	We utilize the factor method to determine the amount of costs to be capitalized and the ending asset balance.
24090_18_ITEM7_P175_S1	The factor method is based on the ratio of premium revenue recognized for the policies in force at the end of each reporting period compared to the premium revenue recognized for policies in force at the beginning of the reporting period.
24090_18_ITEM7_P175_S2	The factor method ensures that policies which lapsed or surrendered during the reporting period are no longer included in the deferred policy acquisition costs calculation.
24090_18_ITEM7_P175_S3	The factor method limits the amount of deferred costs to its estimated realizable value, provided actual experience is comparable to that contemplated in the factors.
24090_18_ITEM7_P176_S0	Inherent in the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs are certain management judgments about what acquisition costs are deferred, the ending asset balance and the annual amortization.
24090_18_ITEM7_P176_S1	Approximately 95.0% of our capitalized deferred acquisition costs are attributed to first year and renewal excess commissions.
24090_18_ITEM7_P176_S2	The remaining 5.0% are attributed to other costs that vary with and are directly related to the successful acquisition of new insurance business.
24090_18_ITEM7_P176_S3	Those costs generally include costs related to the production, underwriting and issuance of new business.
24090_18_ITEM7_P177_S0	DAC is subject to recoverability testing at the time of policy issuance and loss recognition testing on an annual basis, or when an event occurs that might require loss recognition testing.
24090_18_ITEM7_P177_S1	If loss recognition or impairment is necessary, DAC would be written off to the extent that anticipated future premiums and investment income is insufficient to cover expected future policy benefits and expenses.
24090_18_ITEM7_P178_S0	Loss recognition testing that considers, among other things, actual experience and projected future experience calculates the available premium (gross premium less the benefit and expense portion of premium) for the next 50 years.
24090_18_ITEM7_P179_S0	premium per policy and the deferred policy acquisition costs per policy are then calculated.
24090_18_ITEM7_P179_S1	The deferred policy acquisition costs are then evaluated for recoverability using best estimate assumptions.
24090_18_ITEM7_P179_S2	Management believes that our deferred policy acquisition costs and related amortization for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 limits the amount of deferred costs to its estimated realizable value.
24090_18_ITEM7_P179_S3	This belief is based upon the analysis performed on capitalized expenses that vary with and are directly related to the acquisition of new and renewal insurance business, utilization of the factor method and recoverability testing at the time of policy issuance and the annual loss recognition testing.
24090_18_ITEM7_P180_S0	Cost of Customer Relationships Acquired ("CCRA") is established when we purchase a block of insurance.
24090_18_ITEM7_P180_S1	CCRA is amortized primarily over the emerging profit of the related policies using the same assumptions as were used in computing liabilities for future policy benefits.
24090_18_ITEM7_P181_S0	We utilize various methods to determine the amount of the ending asset balance, including a static model and a dynamic model.
24090_18_ITEM7_P181_S1	Inherent in the amortization of CCRA are certain management judgments about the ending asset balance and the annual amortization.
24090_18_ITEM7_P181_S2	The assumptions used are based upon interest, mortality and lapses at the time of purchase.
24090_18_ITEM7_P182_S0	A recoverability test that considers, among other things, actual experience and projected future experience is performed at least annually.
24090_18_ITEM7_P182_S1	These annual recoverability tests initially calculate the available premium (gross premium less benefit and expense portion of premium) for the next 50 years.
24090_18_ITEM7_P182_S2	The CCRA is then evaluated for recoverability utilizing best estimate assumptions.
24090_18_ITEM7_P182_S3	Management believes our CCRA and related amortization is recoverable for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 .
24090_18_ITEM7_P182_S4	This belief is based upon the analysis performed on estimated future results of the block and our annual recoverability testing.
24090_18_ITEM7_P183_S0	Current accounting guidance requires that goodwill balances be reviewed for impairment at least annually or more frequently if events occur or circumstances change that would indicate that a triggering event has occurred.
24090_18_ITEM7_P184_S0	A reporting unit is defined as an operating segment on one level below an operating segment.
24090_18_ITEM7_P184_S1	Most of the Company's reporting units, for which goodwill has been allocated, are equivalent to the Company's operating segment, as there is no discrete financial information reviewed and analyzed by management for the separate components of the segment or all of the components of the segment have similar economic characteristics.
24090_18_ITEM7_P185_S0	The Company historically has performed a goodwill impairment test that follows a multi-step process as defined under current accounting guidance.
24090_18_ITEM7_P185_S1	An initial review may be performed whereby the assessment is based upon qualitative factors before performing the first test step.
24090_18_ITEM7_P186_S0	In the first step, the fair value of a reporting unit is compared to its carrying value.
24090_18_ITEM7_P186_S1	If the carrying value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the impairment test is performed for purposes of measuring the impairment.
24090_18_ITEM7_P186_S2	In the second step, the fair value of the reporting unit is allocated to all of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit to determine an implied goodwill value.
24090_18_ITEM7_P186_S3	If the carrying amount of the reporting unit goodwill exceeds the implied goodwill value, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to that excess.
24090_18_ITEM7_P187_S0	No. 2017-04, Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairmen t as discussed in Part IV, Note 1 - "Summary of Significant Accounting Policies".
24090_18_ITEM7_P188_S0	This ASU eliminates the step two test as noted above.
24090_18_ITEM7_P189_S0	Management s determination of the fair value of each reporting unit incorporates multiple inputs including discounted cash flow calculations based on assumptions that market participants would make in valuing the reporting unit.
24090_18_ITEM7_P189_S1	Other assumptions can include levels of economic capital, future business growth, and earnings projections.
24090_18_ITEM7_P190_S0	The evaluation of securities for impairments is a quantitative and qualitative process, which is subject to risks and uncertainties and is intended to determine whether declines in the fair value of investments should be recognized in current period earnings.
24090_18_ITEM7_P190_S1	The risks and uncertainties include changes in general economic conditions, the issuer's financial condition or future prospects, the effects of changes in interest rates or credit spreads and the expected recovery period.
24090_18_ITEM7_P191_S0	Based upon current accounting guidance, investment securities must be classified as held-to-maturity, available-for-sale or trading.
24090_18_ITEM7_P191_S1	Management determines the appropriate classification at the time of purchase.
24090_18_ITEM7_P192_S0	The classification of securities is significant since it directly impacts the accounting for unrealized gains and losses on securities.
24090_18_ITEM7_P193_S0	held-to-maturity and carried at amortized cost when management has the positive intent and the Company has the ability to hold the securities to maturity.
24090_18_ITEM7_P193_S1	Securities not classified as held-to-maturity are classified as available-for-sale and are carried at fair value, with the unrealized holding gains and losses, net of tax, reported in other comprehensive income and do not affect earnings until realized.
24090_18_ITEM7_P194_S0	The Company evaluates all securities on a quarterly basis, and more frequently when economic conditions warrant additional evaluations, for determining if an OTTI exists pursuant to the accounting guidelines.
24090_18_ITEM7_P194_S1	In evaluating the possible impairment of securities, consideration is given to the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has been less than cost, the financial conditions and near-term prospects of the issuer, and the ability and intent of the Company to retain its investment in the issuer for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in fair value.
24090_18_ITEM7_P194_S2	In analyzing an issuer's financial condition, the Company may consider whether the securities are issued by the Federal government or its agencies, by government-sponsored agencies, or whether downgrades by bond rating agencies have occurred, and reviews of the issuer's financial condition.
24090_18_ITEM7_P195_S0	If management determines that an investment experienced an OTTI, management must then determine the amount of OTTI to be recognized in earnings.
24090_18_ITEM7_P195_S1	If management does not intend to sell the security and it is more likely than not that the Company will not be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period loss, the OTTI will be separated into the amount representing the credit loss and the amount related to all other factors.
24090_18_ITEM7_P195_S2	The amount of OTTI related to the credit loss is determined based on the present value of cash flows expected to be collected and is recognized in earnings.
24090_18_ITEM7_P195_S3	The amount of OTTI related to other factors will be recognized in other comprehensive income, net of applicable taxes.
24090_18_ITEM7_P195_S4	The previous amortized cost basis less the OTTI recognized in earnings will become the new amortized cost basis of the investment.
24090_18_ITEM7_P195_S5	If management intends to sell the security or more likely than not will be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period credit loss, the OTTI will be recognized in earnings equal to the entire difference between the investment's amortized cost basis and its fair value at the balance sheet date.
24090_18_ITEM7_P195_S6	Any recoveries related to the value of these securities are recorded as an unrealized gain (as other comprehensive income (loss) in shareholders' equity) and not recognized in income until the security is ultimately sold.
24090_18_ITEM7_P196_S0	The Company from time to time may dispose of an impaired security in response to asset/liability management decisions, future market movements, business plan changes, or if the net proceeds can be reinvested at a rate of return that is expected to recover the loss within a reasonable period of time.
24090_18_ITEM7_P197_S0	Premiums on life and accident and health policies are reported as earned when due or, for short duration contracts, over the contract period on a pro rata basis.
24090_18_ITEM7_P197_S1	Benefits and expenses are associated with earned premiums so as to result in recognition of profits over the estimated life of the contracts.
24090_18_ITEM7_P197_S2	This matching is accomplished by means of provisions for future benefits and the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs.
24090_18_ITEM7_P198_S0	Annuities are accounted for in a manner consistent with accounting for interest bearing financial instruments.
24090_18_ITEM7_P199_S0	Our primary annuity products do not include fees or other such charges.
24090_18_ITEM7_P200_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the estimated future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases.
24090_18_ITEM7_P200_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
24090_18_ITEM7_P200_S2	The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in net income in the period in which the change is enacted.
24090_18_ITEM7_P200_S3	Given the enactment of the New Tax Act on December 22, 2017, we have re-measured our deferred tax assets and deferred tax liabilities to the new corporate tax rate of 21% which resulted in a $35.7 million tax expense.
24090_18_ITEM7_P201_S0	An estimated loss from a contingency is accrued and charged to results of operations only if both of the following conditions are met:
24090_18_ITEM7_P202_S0	The amount of the loss can be reasonably estimated.
24090_18_ITEM7_P203_S0	Reasonable estimation of a possible loss does not require estimating a single amount of the loss.
24090_18_ITEM7_P203_S1	It requires that a loss be accrued if it can be estimated within a range.
24090_18_ITEM7_P203_S2	If an amount within the range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, that amount is accrued.
24090_18_ITEM7_P203_S3	If no amount within the range is a better estimate than any other amount, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.
24090_18_ITEM7_P204_S0	A gain contingency is an uncertain situation that will be resolved in the future, possibly resulting in a gain.
24090_18_ITEM7_P204_S1	We do not allow the recognition of a gain contingency prior to settlement of the underlying event.
24090_18_ITEM7_P204_S2	If we were to have a gain contingency, we would disclose it in the notes to the financial statements.
24090_18_ITEM7_P205_S0	"Financial Statements and Supplementary Data," and Note 1 - "Accounting Pronouncements" to the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The nature of our business exposes us to market risk relative to our invested assets and policy liabilities.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Market risk is the risk of loss that may occur when changes in interest rates and public equity prices adversely affect the value of our invested assets.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Interest rate risk is our primary market risk exposure.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P0_S3	Substantial and sustained increases and decreases in market interest rates can affect the fair value of our investments.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P0_S4	The fair value of our fixed maturity portfolio generally increases when interest rates decrease and decreases when interest rates increase.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The following table summarizes net unrealized gains and losses as of the dates indicated.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Our exposure to interest rate changes results from our significant holdings of fixed maturity investments, policy loans and mortgage loans on real estate, all of which comprised over 94.8% of our cash and investment portfolio as of December 31, 2017 .
24090_18_ITEM7A_P2_S1	These investments are mainly exposed to changes in U.S. Treasury rates.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Our fixed maturities investments include U.S. Government-sponsored enterprises, U.S. Government bonds, securities issued by government agencies, state and municipal bonds, and corporate bonds.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Approximately 64.8% of the fixed maturities we owned at market value on December 31, 2017 are state and political subdivisions which are primarily municipal holdings.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P2_S4	These holdings are diversified over several states though approximately 40% of our state and municipal securities are concentrated in three states - Texas, Florida and Louisiana.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Changes in interest rates typically have a sizable effect on the fair value of our debt and equities securities.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The interest rate of the ten-year U.S. Treasury bond decreased to 2.40% at December 31, 2017 , from 2.45% at December 31, 2016 .
24090_18_ITEM7A_P3_S2	Net unrealized gains on fixed maturity securities totaled $46.0 million at December 31, 2017 , compared to $26.7 million at December 31, 2016 , based upon bond interest rates in relation to the U. S. ten-year Treasury yield.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P4_S0	To manage interest risk, we perform periodic projections of asset and liability cash flows to evaluate the potential sensitivity of our investments and liabilities.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P5_S0	We assess interest rate sensitivity on an annual basis with respect to our fixed maturities investments using hypothetical test scenarios that assume either upward or downward shifts in the prevailing interest rates.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The Company performed an analysis of fair value changes using assumed 100 basis point shifts in interest rates, noting that the fair value of our fixed maturity investment portfolio of $1.2 billion would decrease approximately $9.6 million to a fair value of $1.2 billion upon a 100 basis point increase.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P5_S2	The following table shows the effects on the fair values of our fixed maturity investments based upon these scenarios.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P6_S0	While the test scenarios are for illustrative purposes only and do not reflect our expectations regarding future interest rates or the performance of fixed-income markets, it is a near-term change that illustrates the potential impact of such events.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P7_S0	Due to the composition of our book of insurance business, we believe it is unlikely we would encounter large surrender activity due to an interest rate increase that would force us to dispose of our fixed maturities at a loss.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P8_S0	Our fixed maturity portfolio is exposed to call risk as a significant portion of the current holdings are callable.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P8_S1	A decreasing interest rate environment can result in increased call activity as experienced over the past several years, and an increasing rate environment will likely result in securities being paid at their stated maturity.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P9_S0	There are no fixed maturities or other investments that we classify as trading instruments.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P9_S1	Approximately 80.1% of fixed maturities were held in available-for-sale and 19.9% in held-to-maturity based upon fair value at December 31, 2017 .
24090_18_ITEM7A_P9_S2	At December 31, 2017 and 2016 , we had no investments in derivative instruments, subprime loans or CDOs (collateralized debt obligations).
24090_18_ITEM7A_P10_S0	Changes in the level or volatility of equity prices affect the value of equity securities we hold as investments.
24090_18_ITEM7A_P10_S1	Our equity investments portfolio represented 1.2% of our total investments at December 31, 2017 , with 96.4% invested in diversified equity and bond mutual funds.

24090_18_ITEM9A_P0_S0	We maintain disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act )) that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in our reports filed or submitted under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our principal executive officer and principal financial officer, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosures.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our management, including our principal executive officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting officer and principal operating officer evaluated the effectiveness of our disclosure controls and procedures pursuant to Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act as of December 31, 2017, the end of the period covered by this Annual Report on form 10-K. Based on such evaluation, our principal executive officer and principal financial officer concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were not effective due to the material weaknesses in internal control over financial reporting described below.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f).
24090_18_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Management evaluated the design and operating effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ("COSO 2013").
24090_18_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Based on this evaluation, management has concluded that our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2017 was not effective due to the material weaknesses described below.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P3_S0	A material weakness, as defined in Exchange Act Rule 12b-2, is a deficiency, or combination of deficiencies, in internal control over financial reporting, such that there is a reasonable possibility that a material misstatement of our annual or interim financial statements will not be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P4_S0	We did not have a sufficient number of competent individuals to design, document, maintain, and execute an appropriate system of controls.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P4_S1	In addition, the Company did not provide comprehensive employee training covering COSO 2013 internal control awareness, as required.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P4_S2	As a result, we identified control deficiencies in aggregate that constitute material weaknesses in each of the five components of internal control as defined by COSO 2013 (control environment, risk assessment, control activities, information and communication, and monitoring), which resulted in more than a remote likelihood that a material misstatement of our annual or interim financial statements would not be prevented or detected.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P4_S3	In part, management identified deficiencies related to its internal staff competency and expertise related to information technology, internal audit, and certain management estimates.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P4_S4	As a result of these deficiencies, the Company did not design and maintain effective:
24090_18_ITEM9A_P5_S0	Information technology controls, which includes information security, systems change management and computer operations for systems and applications that are critical to processing financial transactions and capturing and reporting information in the financial reporting process.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P6_S0	Controls over the accuracy and completeness of spreadsheets and system-generated reports.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P7_S0	Controls related to monitoring of information provided by third party service providers for the preparation of certain management estimates, including but not limited to the valuation of certain insurance reserves and the computation of income taxes.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P7_S1	Management has concluded that the Company s outsourced service provider policy that governs the data validation controls over data provided to and received from third party service providers and the monitoring, business process and management review controls were not designed with appropriate levels of precision.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P8_S0	Our independent registered public accounting firm, Deloitte Touche LLP, has issued an attestation report on the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P8_S1	The report is included in item 9A(c) of this annual report.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P9_S0	To the Shareholders and the Board of Directors of Citizens, Inc.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P10_S0	Opinion on Internal Control over Financial Reporting We have audited the internal control over financial reporting of Citizens, Inc. and consolidated subsidiaries (the Company ) as of December 31, 2017, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
24090_18_ITEM9A_P10_S1	In our opinion, because of the effect of the material weaknesses identified below on the achievement of the objectives of the control criteria, the Company has not maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2017, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by COSO.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P10_S2	We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) (PCAOB), the consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2017, of the Company and our report dated March 29, 2018 , expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial statements.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P10_S3	Basis for Opinion The Company s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P10_S4	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P10_S5	We are a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB and are required to be independent with respect to the Company in accordance with the U.S. federal securities laws and the applicable rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the PCAOB.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P10_S6	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P10_S7	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P10_S8	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P10_S9	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P11_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P11_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P11_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P11_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P12_S0	Material Weaknesses A material weakness is a deficiency, or a combination of deficiencies, in internal control over financial reporting, such that there is a reasonable possibility that a material misstatement of the company s annual or interim financial statements will not be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P12_S1	Management identified material weaknesses in the Company s overall control environment due to the aggregate effect of multiple deficiencies in internal controls, which affected each of the five components of internal control as defined by COSO (control environment, risk assessment, control activities, information and communication, and monitoring).
24090_18_ITEM9A_P13_S0	These material weaknesses were considered in determining the nature, timing, and extent of audit tests applied in our audit of the consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2017, of the Company, and this report does not affect our report on such consolidated financial statements.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P14_S0	There were no changes in the Company s internal controls over financial reporting that occurred during the quarter ended December 31, 2017, that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company s internal controls over financial reporting.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P15_S0	During 2017, management initiated the following remediation efforts to address the identified material weaknesses described above and to enhance our competency within certain areas of the financial control environment, though these efforts cannot be considered fully remediated until the applicable remedial controls are designed and operate for a sufficient period of time and management has concluded, through its evaluation, that the following personnel enhancements to the control environment are in place as of December 31, 2017:
24090_18_ITEM9A_P16_S0	Enhanced our internal control program and remediation efforts by co-sourcing our internal audit function to an experienced, nationally recognized audit firm.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P16_S1	At the direction of management and specifically the internal control task force, the co-sourcing provider will continue to assist the internal control task force to enhance the evaluation of the control environment against the criteria established in COSO 2013.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P17_S0	Added an Interim Chief Information Officer who will focus on enhancing our general IT controls, including required remediation and control improvements.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P18_S0	While the enhancements described above demonstrate a commitment to strengthening the control environment by attracting, developing and retaining competent personnel and outsourced service providers to support the achievement of the Company s objectives, they occurred during the latter half of 2017.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P18_S1	Management intends to take the following actions to further remediate deficiencies during 2018, including enhancing their ability to demonstrate the criteria and principles established in COSO 2013:
24090_18_ITEM9A_P19_S0	Reevaluate the criteria established in COSO 2013 to make further enhancements to entity-level controls in order to demonstrate that our internal controls framework addresses relevant principles and components of COSO 2013.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P20_S0	We believe the remediation steps outlined above have improved and will continue to improve the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting and our COSO 2013 framework as a whole.
24090_18_ITEM9A_P20_S1	We will test the ongoing operating effectiveness of all new controls subsequent to implementation and consider the material weaknesses remediated after the applicable remedial controls operate effectively for a sufficient period of time.

24090_18_ITEM15_P24_S0	Investment securities are classified as held-to-maturity, available-for-sale or trading.
24090_18_ITEM15_P24_S1	Management determines the appropriate classification at the time of purchase.
24090_18_ITEM15_P25_S0	The classification of securities is significant since it directly impacts the accounting for unrealized gains and losses on securities.
24090_18_ITEM15_P25_S1	Fixed maturity securities are classified as held-to-maturity and carried at amortized cost when management has the positive intent and the Company has the ability to hold the securities to maturity.
24090_18_ITEM15_P25_S2	Securities not classified as held-to-maturity are classified as available-for-sale and are carried at fair value, with the unrealized holding gains and losses, net of tax, reported in other comprehensive income and do not affect earnings until realized.
24090_18_ITEM15_P26_S0	Fixed maturities consist primarily of bonds classified as available-for-sale or held-to-maturity.
24090_18_ITEM15_P26_S1	The Company does not classify any fixed maturities as trading.
24090_18_ITEM15_P26_S2	Equity securities (including non-redeemable preferred stock) are considered available-for-sale and are reported at fair value.
24090_18_ITEM15_P27_S0	Unrealized gains (losses) of equity securities and fixed maturities held as available-for-sale is shown as a separate component of stockholders' equity, net of tax, and is a separate component of comprehensive income.
24090_18_ITEM15_P28_S0	The Company evaluates all securities on a quarterly basis, and more frequently when economic conditions warrant additional evaluations, for determining if an other-than-temporary impairment ("OTTI") exists pursuant to the accounting guidelines.
24090_18_ITEM15_P28_S1	In evaluating the possible impairment of securities, consideration is given to the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has been less than cost, the financial conditions and near-term prospects of the issuer, and the ability and intent of the Company to retain its investment in the issuer for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in fair value.
24090_18_ITEM15_P28_S2	In analyzing an issuer s financial condition, the Company may consider whether the securities are issued by the Federal government or its agencies, by government-sponsored agencies, or whether downgrades by bond rating agencies have occurred, and reviews of the issuer s financial condition.
24090_18_ITEM15_P29_S0	If management determines that an investment experienced an OTTI, management must then determine the amount of OTTI to be recognized in earnings.
24090_18_ITEM15_P29_S1	If management does not intend to sell the security and it is more likely than not that the Company will not be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period loss, the OTTI will be separated into the amount representing the credit loss and the amount related to all other factors.
24090_18_ITEM15_P29_S2	The amount of OTTI related to the credit loss is determined based on the present value of cash flows expected to be collected and is recognized in earnings.
24090_18_ITEM15_P30_S0	The previous amortized cost basis less the OTTI recognized in earnings will become the new amortized cost basis of the investment.
24090_18_ITEM15_P30_S1	If management intends to sell the security or more likely than not will be required to sell the security before recovery of its amortized cost basis less any current period credit loss, the OTTI will be recognized in earnings equal to the entire difference between the investment's amortized cost basis and its fair value at the balance sheet date.
24090_18_ITEM15_P30_S2	Any recoveries related to the value of these securities are recorded as an unrealized gain (as other comprehensive income (loss) in stockholders' equity) and not recognized in income until the security is ultimately sold.
24090_18_ITEM15_P31_S0	The Company from time to time may dispose of an impaired security in response to asset/liability management decisions, future market movements, business plan changes, or if the net proceeds can be reinvested at a rate of return that is expected to recover the loss within a reasonable period of time.
24090_18_ITEM15_P32_S0	Mortgage loans on real estate and policy loans are reported at unpaid principal balances.
24090_18_ITEM15_P33_S0	Real estate and other long-term investments consist primarily of land and buildings that are recorded at depreciated cost.
24090_18_ITEM15_P33_S1	If the fair value of the real estate is less than the carrying value, an impairment loss is recognized and charged to earnings.
24090_18_ITEM15_P34_S0	Real estate held for sale represented a building we owned in Arkansas, which was sold in 2017.
24090_18_ITEM15_P35_S0	Premiums and discounts are amortized or accreted over the life of the related security as an adjustment to yield using the effective interest method.
24090_18_ITEM15_P36_S0	Dividend and interest income is recognized when earned.
24090_18_ITEM15_P36_S1	Realized gains and losses are included in earnings and are derived using the specific identification method for determining the cost of securities sold.

24090_18_ITEM15_P38_S0	Premiums on life policies are recognized as earned when due.

24090_18_ITEM15_P39_S0	Accident and health policies are recognized as revenue over the contract period on a pro rata basis.
24090_18_ITEM15_P39_S1	Benefits and expenses are associated with earned premiums so as to result in the recognition of profits over the estimated lives of the contracts.
24090_18_ITEM15_P39_S2	This matching is accomplished by means of a provision for future policy benefits and the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs.
24090_18_ITEM15_P40_S0	Annuity policies, primarily flexible premium fixed annuity products, are accounted for in a manner consistent with accounting for interest bearing financial instruments.

24090_18_ITEM15_P40_S2	The annuity products issued do not include fees or other such charges.
24090_18_ITEM15_P41_S0	Acquisition costs, consisting of commissions and policy issuance, underwriting and agent convention expenses that are directly related to and vary with the successful production of new and renewal business, have been deferred.
24090_18_ITEM15_P41_S1	These deferred amounts, referred to as deferred policy acquisition costs ("DAC"), are recorded as an asset on the consolidated balance sheet and amortized to income in a systematic manner, based on related contract revenues or gross profits as appropriate.
24090_18_ITEM15_P42_S0	Traditional life insurance and accident and health insurance acquisition costs are being amortized over the premium-paying period of the related policies using assumptions consistent with those used in computing future policy benefit liabilities.
24090_18_ITEM15_P42_S1	For universal life type contracts and investment contracts that include significant surrender charges or that yield significant revenues from sources other than the investment contract holders' funds, the deferred contract acquisition cost amortization is matched to the recognition of gross profit.
24090_18_ITEM15_P42_S2	The effect on the DAC asset that would result from realization of unrealized gains or losses is recognized with an offset to accumulated other comprehensive income in consolidated stockholders' equity.
24090_18_ITEM15_P43_S0	through income and any new deferrable costs associated with the new replacement are deferred.
24090_18_ITEM15_P43_S1	If a contract modification does not substantially change the contract, the DAC amortization on the original contract will continue and any acquisition costs associated with the related modification are immediately expensed.
24090_18_ITEM15_P44_S0	We utilize the factor method to determine the amount of costs to be capitalized and the ending asset balance.
24090_18_ITEM15_P44_S1	The factor method is based on the ratio of premium revenue recognized for the policies in force at the end of each reporting period compared to the premium revenue recognized for policies in force at the beginning of the reporting period.
24090_18_ITEM15_P44_S2	The factor method ensures that policies lapsed or surrendered during the reporting period are no longer included in the deferred policy acquisition costs calculation.
24090_18_ITEM15_P44_S3	The factor method limits the amount of deferred costs to its estimated realizable value, provided actual experience is comparable to that contemplated in the factors.
24090_18_ITEM15_P45_S0	Inherent in the capitalization and amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs are certain management judgments about what acquisition costs are deferred, the ending asset balance and the annual amortization.
24090_18_ITEM15_P45_S1	Approximately 95% of our capitalized deferred acquisition costs are attributed to first year and renewal excess commissions.
24090_18_ITEM15_P45_S2	The remaining 5% are attributed to costs that vary with and are directly related to the successful acquisition of new insurance business.
24090_18_ITEM15_P45_S3	Those costs generally include costs related to the production, underwriting and issuance of new business.
24090_18_ITEM15_P46_S0	DAC is subject to recoverability testing at the time of policy issuance and loss recognition testing on an annual basis, or when an event occurs that might require loss recognition testing.
24090_18_ITEM15_P46_S1	If loss recognition or impairment is necessary, DAC would be written off to the extent that anticipated future premiums and investment income is insufficient to cover expected future policy benefits and expenses.
24090_18_ITEM15_P47_S0	Loss recognition testing that considers, among other things, actual experience and projected future experience calculates the available premium (gross premium less the benefit and expense portion of premium) for the next 50 years.
24090_18_ITEM15_P47_S1	The available premium per policy and the deferred policy acquisition costs per policy are then calculated.
24090_18_ITEM15_P47_S2	The deferred policy acquisition costs are then evaluated for recoverability using best estimate assumptions.

24090_18_ITEM15_P47_S4	This belief is based upon the analysis performed on capitalized expenses that vary with and are directly related to the acquisition of new and renewal insurance business, utilization of the factor method and recoverability testing at the time of policy issuance and the annual loss recognition testing.

24090_18_ITEM15_P63_S0	The goodwill impairment test uses a two-step process as set forth under current accounting guidance.
24090_18_ITEM15_P63_S1	In the first step, the fair value of a reporting unit is compared to its carrying value.
24090_18_ITEM15_P63_S2	If the carrying value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the impairment test is performed for purposes of measuring the impairment.
24090_18_ITEM15_P63_S3	In the second step, the fair value of projected new business is compared to the carrying value of goodwill.
24090_18_ITEM15_P63_S4	A requirement of this method is that the inforce must pass loss recognition testing.
24090_18_ITEM15_P63_S5	If the carrying amount of the reporting unit goodwill exceeds the fair value of projected new business, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to that excess.
24090_18_ITEM15_P64_S0	No. 2017-04, Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairmen t.
24090_18_ITEM15_P64_S1	An entity will no longer perform a hypothetical purchase price allocation to measure impairment, eliminating step 2 of the goodwill impairment test.
24090_18_ITEM15_P64_S2	Instead, impairment will be measured using the difference of the carrying amount to the fair value of the reporting unit.
24090_18_ITEM15_P64_S3	The ASU is effective prospectively for annual and interim periods in fiscal year beginning after December 15, 2019, but early adoption is permitted for goodwill impairment tests with measurement dates after January 1, 2017.
24090_18_ITEM15_P64_S4	The Company elected to early adopt this ASU for our 2017 annual evaluation.

24090_18_ITEM15_P65_S1	Other assumptions can include levels of economic capital, future business growth, and earnings projections.

24090_18_ITEM15_P83_S0	An estimated loss from a contingency is accrued and charged to results of operations only if both of the following conditions are met:
24090_18_ITEM15_P84_S0	Information available prior to the issuance of the financial statements indicates that it is probable (virtual certainty is not required) that an asset has been impaired or a liability incurred as of the date of the financial statements; and 2.
24090_18_ITEM15_P84_S1	The amount of the loss can be reasonably estimated.
24090_18_ITEM15_P85_S0	Reasonable estimation of a possible loss does not require estimating a single amount of the loss.
24090_18_ITEM15_P85_S1	It requires that a loss be accrued if it can be estimated within a range.
24090_18_ITEM15_P85_S2	If an amount within the range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, that amount is accrued.
24090_18_ITEM15_P85_S3	If no amount within the range is a better estimate than any other amount, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.
24090_18_ITEM15_P86_S0	A gain contingency is an uncertain situation that will be resolved in the future, possibly resulting in a gain.
24090_18_ITEM15_P86_S1	We do not allow the recognition of a gain contingency prior to settlement of the underlying event.
24090_18_ITEM15_P86_S2	If we were to have a material gain contingency, we would disclose it in the notes to the consolidated financial statements.

24090_18_ITEM15_P91_S0	On May 21, 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-09, Disclosures about Short-Duration Contracts , addressing enhanced disclosure requirements for insurers relating to short-duration insurance contract claims and the unpaid claims liability rollforward for long and short-duration contracts.
24090_18_ITEM15_P91_S1	The disclosures are intended to provide users of financial statements with more transparent information about an insurance entity s initial claim estimates and subsequent adjustments to those estimates, the methodologies and judgments used to estimate claims, and the timing, frequency, and severity of claims.
24090_18_ITEM15_P91_S2	The new disclosures required the accumulation and reporting of new and different groupings of claims data than previously reported.
24090_18_ITEM15_P91_S3	For public business entities, the new guidance is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2015.
24090_18_ITEM15_P92_S0	No. 2017-04, Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairmen t.
24090_18_ITEM15_P92_S1	An entity will no longer perform a hypothetical purchase price allocation to measure impairment, eliminating step 2 of the goodwill impairment test.
24090_18_ITEM15_P92_S2	Instead, impairment will be measured using the difference of the carrying amount to the fair value of the reporting unit.
24090_18_ITEM15_P93_S0	beginning after December 15, 2019, but early adoption is permitted for goodwill impairment tests with measurement dates after January 1, 2017.
24090_18_ITEM15_P93_S1	The Company elected to early adopt this ASU for our 2017 annual evaluation.
24090_18_ITEM15_P94_S0	No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606), which supersedes the revenue recognition requirements in ASC 605, Revenue Recognition.
24090_18_ITEM15_P95_S0	The core principle of ASU 2014-09 is that an entity should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
24090_18_ITEM15_P95_S1	The guidance provides a five-step process to achieve that core principle.
24090_18_ITEM15_P96_S0	ASU 2014-09 requires disclosures enabling users of financial statements to understand the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers.
24090_18_ITEM15_P96_S1	Additionally, qualitative and quantitative disclosures are required about contracts with customers, significant judgments and changes in judgments, and assets recognized from the costs to obtain or fulfill a contract.
24090_18_ITEM15_P97_S0	ASU 2014-09 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period, using one of two retrospective application methods.
24090_18_ITEM15_P98_S0	We have evaluated the effect the guidance will have on our consolidated financial statements.
24090_18_ITEM15_P98_S1	We do not expect that any portion of our revenue will be affected by the new standard, primarily as the new guidance does not apply to revenue from insurance contracts and our non-insurance subsidiaries do not receive revenues from customers.
24090_18_ITEM15_P99_S0	The FASB s new lease accounting standard, ASU 2016-02, Leases (Topic 842) , was issued on February 25, 2016.
24090_18_ITEM15_P99_S1	The ASU will require organizations that lease assets, referred to as lessees , to recognize on the balance sheet the assets and liabilities for the rights and obligations created by those leases.
24090_18_ITEM15_P99_S2	The ASU also will require disclosures to help investors and other financial statement users better understand the amount, timing, and uncertainty of cash flows arising from leases.
24090_18_ITEM15_P99_S3	These disclosures include qualitative and quantitative requirements, providing additional information about the amounts recorded in the financial statements.
24090_18_ITEM15_P100_S0	The accounting by organizations that own the assets leased by the lessee, also known as lessor accounting, will remain largely unchanged from current U.S. GAAP.
24090_18_ITEM15_P100_S1	However, the ASU contains some targeted improvements that are intended to align, where necessary, lessor accounting with the lessee accounting model and with the updated revenue recognition guidance issued in 2014.
24090_18_ITEM15_P101_S0	The ASU on leases will take effect for public companies for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2018.
24090_18_ITEM15_P101_S1	The Company is assessing the impact of this new standard.
24090_18_ITEM15_P102_S0	In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-13, Financial Instruments-Credit Losses (Topic 326) , with the main objective to provide financial statement users with more decision-useful information about the expected credit losses on financial instruments and other commitments to extend credit held by a reporting entity at each reporting date.
24090_18_ITEM15_P102_S1	The amendments in this ASU require a financial asset (or a group of financial assets) measured at amortized cost basis to be presented at the net amount expected to be collected.
24090_18_ITEM15_P103_S0	The allowance for credit losses is a valuation account that is deducted from the amortized cost basis of the financial asset(s) to present the net carrying value at the amount expected to be collected on the financial asset.
24090_18_ITEM15_P103_S1	The income statement reflects the measurement of credit losses for newly recognized financial assets, as well as the expected increases or decreases of expected credit losses that have taken place during the period.
24090_18_ITEM15_P103_S2	Credit losses on available-for-sale debt securities should be measured in a manner similar to current U.S. GAAP; however, the credit losses are recorded through an allowance for credit losses rather than as a write-down.
24090_18_ITEM15_P103_S3	This approach is an improvement to current U.S. GAAP because an entity will be able to record reversals of credit losses (in situations in which the estimate of credit losses declines) in current period net income, which in turn should align the income statement recognition of credit losses with the reporting period in which changes occur.
24090_18_ITEM15_P103_S4	Current U.S. GAAP prohibits reflecting those improvements in current-period earnings.
24090_18_ITEM15_P103_S5	For public business entities, the amendments in this ASU are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
24090_18_ITEM15_P103_S6	The Company is evaluating the impact this guidance will have on our consolidated financial statements, but it is not expected to have a significant impact on the Company's consolidated financial statements.
24090_18_ITEM15_P104_S0	No. 2017-08, Receivables-Nonrefundable Fees and Other Costs (Subtopic 310-20).
24090_18_ITEM15_P104_S1	The amendments in this ASU shorten the amortization period for certain callable debt securities held at a premium.
24090_18_ITEM15_P104_S2	Specifically, the amendments require the premium to be amortized to the earliest call date.
24090_18_ITEM15_P104_S3	The amendments do not require an accounting change for securities held at a discount; the discount continues to be amortized to maturity.
24090_18_ITEM15_P105_S0	The Company has a large portfolio of callable debt securities purchased at a premium.
24090_18_ITEM15_P105_S1	As such, the Company had already been amortizing the premium to the earliest call date to reduce volatility in earnings by eliminating reporting large realized losses when debt securities are called.
24090_18_ITEM15_P105_S2	For public business entities, the amendments in this Update are effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2018.

24090_18_ITEM15_P131_S0	Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
24090_18_ITEM15_P131_S1	We hold fixed maturity and equity securities that are carried at fair value.
24090_18_ITEM15_P132_S0	Fair value measurements are generally based upon observable and unobservable inputs.
24090_18_ITEM15_P132_S1	Observable inputs reflect market data obtained from independent sources, while unobservable inputs reflect our view of market assumptions in the absence of observable market information.
24090_18_ITEM15_P132_S2	We utilize valuation techniques that maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs.
24090_18_ITEM15_P133_S0	All assets and liabilities carried at fair value are required to be classified and disclosed in one of the following three categories:
24090_18_ITEM15_P134_S0	Level 1 - Quoted prices for identical instruments in active markets.
24090_18_ITEM15_P135_S0	Level 2 - Quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets; quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active and model-derived valuations whose inputs or whose significant value drivers are observable.
24090_18_ITEM15_P136_S0	Level 3 - Instruments whose significant value drivers are unobservable.
24090_18_ITEM15_P137_S0	Level 1 primarily consists of financial instruments whose value is based on quoted market prices such as U.S. Treasury securities, publicly traded mutual fund investments and individual stocks.
24090_18_ITEM15_P138_S0	Level 2 includes those financial instruments that are valued by independent pricing services or broker quotes.
24090_18_ITEM15_P138_S1	These models are primarily industry-standard models that consider various inputs, such as interest rates, credit spreads and foreign exchange rates for the underlying financial instruments.
24090_18_ITEM15_P138_S2	All significant inputs are observable, or derived from observable information in the marketplace or are supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
24090_18_ITEM15_P139_S0	Financial instruments in this category primarily include corporate fixed maturity securities, U.S. Government-sponsored enterprise securities, municipal securities and certain mortgage and asset-backed securities.
24090_18_ITEM15_P140_S0	Level 3 is comprised of financial instruments whose fair value is estimated based on non-binding broker prices utilizing significant inputs not based on, or corroborated by, readily available market information.
24090_18_ITEM15_P140_S1	We have no level 3 assets as of December 31, 2017 .
24090_18_ITEM15_P141_S0	The following table sets forth our assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value on a recurring basis as of the date indicated.
24090_18_ITEM15_P142_S0	At December 31, 2017 , the fixed maturities, valued using a third-party pricing source, totaled $962.8 million for Level 2 assets and comprised 97.2% of total reported fair value.
24090_18_ITEM15_P142_S1	Fair values for Level 3 assets are based upon unadjusted broker quotes that are non-binding.
24090_18_ITEM15_P143_S0	The Level 1 and Level 2 valuations are reviewed and validated quarterly through random testing by comparisons to separate pricing models, other third party pricing services, and back tested to recent trades.
24090_18_ITEM15_P143_S1	In addition, we obtain information relative to the third party pricing models and review model parameters for reasonableness.
24090_18_ITEM15_P143_S2	For the period ended December 31, 2017 , there were no material changes to the valuation methods or assumptions used to determine fair values, and no broker or third party prices were changed from the values received.
24090_18_ITEM15_P144_S0	There were no transfers made between Levels 1 and 2 securities at December 31, 2017 or 2016 .

24090_18_ITEM15_P176_S0	On June 10, 2016, the National Association of Insurance Commissioners ( NAIC ) Executive Committee and Plenary voted to adopt a recommendation for January 1, 2017 as the operative date for the implementation of Principles-Based Reserves ( PBR ) as a national standard for life insurance products.
24090_18_ITEM15_P176_S1	Although this NAIC standard does not change the reserving requirements under U.S. GAAP, it can be significant for many life insurers.
24090_18_ITEM15_P177_S0	PBR replaces the current formulaic approach to determining policy reserves with an approach that more closely reflects the risks of highly complex products.
24090_18_ITEM15_P177_S1	Companies will be expected to develop right-sized reserves that better align with their specific product features, their observed actuarial experience, and their overall risk management procedures.
24090_18_ITEM15_P177_S2	There is a three-year transition period where PBR is optional until PBR becomes required on January 1, 2020.
24090_18_ITEM15_P177_S3	The Company is assessing the impact that this standard will have on its statutory reserving and capital and surplus.
24090_18_ITEM15_P178_S0	As of December 31, 2014, we reported that a portion of the life insurance policies issued by our subsidiary insurance companies failed to qualify for the favorable U.S. federal income tax treatment afforded by Section 7702 of the Internal Revenue Code ("IRC") of 1986.
24090_18_ITEM15_P178_S1	This tax code section allows for qualifying products sold to clients to have favorable tax treatment such as the product's inside build up is not taxable, unless distributions are made.
24090_18_ITEM15_P178_S2	Because these policies were sold with the intention that they would qualify for this favorable tax treatment, holders of these policies and the Company may now be subject to additional tax liabilities.
24090_18_ITEM15_P179_S0	The policies at issue were sold most substantially to non-U.S. citizens residing abroad and to a lesser extent domestically.
24090_18_ITEM15_P179_S1	Based upon a review of the options available to the Company, we have determined we will not remediate our endowments and life products that we have sold to non-U.S. citizens but will propose an offer to the IRS to settle potential liabilities.
24090_18_ITEM15_P179_S2	We do intend to remediate the domestic products we have sold to U.S. citizens.
24090_18_ITEM15_P179_S3	Accordingly, we submitted an offer to enter into a Closing Agreement for CICA and CNLIC in May 2017.
24090_18_ITEM15_P179_S4	We have not received a response from the IRS on this submission.
24090_18_ITEM15_P179_S5	In addition, as part of our continuing review, we determined in July 2015 that certain annuity contracts do not contain qualifying language under IRC 72(s) as intended that would have provided for favorable tax treatment of the annuities.
24090_18_ITEM15_P179_S6	This issue affects both our domestic and international contract holders.
24090_18_ITEM15_P179_S7	We generally endorsed affected domestic annuity contracts to comply with the Code in December 2017 and intend to submit a Closing Agreement offer in 2018 to address past non-compliance.
24090_18_ITEM15_P179_S8	The Company has continued to refine the understanding of the tax failures as previously reported by preparing an individual policy calculation and has reflected the related exposure for the current reporting period as noted below.
24090_18_ITEM15_P179_S9	Failure of these policies to qualify under IRC Sections 7702 and 72(s) has resulted in additional liabilities and expenses as described below.
24090_18_ITEM15_P180_S0	The products have been and continue to be appropriately reported under U.S. GAAP for financial reporting.
24090_18_ITEM15_P181_S0	The failure of these policies to qualify under Sections 7702 and 72(s) results in an estimated liability as of December 31, 2017 of $12.3 million, after tax, related to projected IRS toll charges and fees of $12.0 million and reserves increases to bring policies into compliance totaling $0.3 million.
24090_18_ITEM15_P181_S1	The estimated liability at December 31, 2017 is down $2.1 million from the estimated liability at December 31, 2016 of $14.4 million , after tax, due to a continued refinement of our estimate and additional accrued interest charges.
24090_18_ITEM15_P181_S2	The probability weighted range of financial estimates relative to this issue is $5.9 million to $48.2 million , after tax.
24090_18_ITEM15_P181_S3	This estimated range includes projected toll charges and fees payable to the IRS, as well as estimated increased payout obligations to current holders of non-compliant domestic life insurance policies expected to result from remediation of those policies.
24090_18_ITEM15_P181_S4	The estimated liability and the estimated range will be updated as we continue to refine our estimates.
24090_18_ITEM15_P181_S5	The amount of our liabilities and expenses depends on a number of uncertainties, including the number of prior tax years for which we may be liable to the IRS, the number of domestic life insurance policies we will be required to remediate, and the methodology applicable to the calculation of the toll charge for non-compliant policies.
24090_18_ITEM15_P181_S6	Given the range of potential outcomes and the significant variables assumed in establishing our estimates, actual amounts incurred may exceed our reserve and also could exceed the high end of our estimated range of liabilities and expenses.
24090_18_ITEM15_P181_S7	To the extent the amount reserved by the Company is insufficient to meet the actual amount of our liability and expenses, or if our estimates of those liabilities and expenses change in the future, our financial condition and results of operations may be materially adversely affected.
24090_18_ITEM15_P181_S8	Management believes that based upon current information we have recorded the best estimate liability to date.
24090_18_ITEM15_P182_S0	Accruals for loss contingencies are recorded when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated.
24090_18_ITEM15_P182_S1	The process of determining our best estimate and the estimated range was a complex undertaking including insight from external consultants and involved management s judgment based upon a variety of factors known at the time.
24090_18_ITEM15_P182_S2	Additional costs will be incurred in 2018 associated with these issues and we believe these costs will range from $1.0 million to $2.0 million , but due to the uncertainty of actions we cannot reasonably estimate these costs with any reliability.
24090_18_ITEM15_P182_S3	Actual amounts incurred may exceed this estimate and will be recorded as they become probable and can be reasonably estimated.

24090_18_ITEM15_P229_S0	Correction of Immaterial Errors In the course of preparing its consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2016, the Company identified immaterial errors in its previously filed financial statements.
24090_18_ITEM15_P229_S1	The errors were in the Company s accounting for DAC and future policy benefits in the life insurance segment and several other immaterial errors in our other two segments.
24090_18_ITEM15_P229_S2	Two of the errors were discovered in connection with the Company s ongoing conversion of its actuarial valuation from a third party service provider to an actuarial valuation modeling software system purchased from a vendor.
24090_18_ITEM15_P229_S3	The errors in valuing DAC and future policy benefits caused the Company to understate amortization of DAC over several years and to overstate the increase in future policy benefit reserves during the same periods, resulting in an overstatement of DAC of $0.3 million and an overstatement of future policy benefits of $7.9 million at December 31, 2015.
24090_18_ITEM15_P229_S4	There were several other immaterial errors that resulted in negligible impact at December 31, 2015.
24090_18_ITEM15_P229_S5	Correcting the errors resulted in a reduction in the Company s net losses of $0.4 million in 2015.
24090_18_ITEM15_P230_S0	No. 99, Materiality , and SAB No. 108, Considering the Effects of Prior Year Misstatements when Quantifying Misstatements in Current Year Financial Statements and determined that the errors were immaterial to each of the previously reported periods.
24090_18_ITEM15_P230_S1	However, the Company determined that the adjustment to correct the error, if recorded in 2016 operating results, would materially misstate the 2016 financial statements.
24090_18_ITEM15_P230_S2	Accordingly, we are correcting the errors by restating the prior period information, and therefore have revised the Consolidated Statement of Financial Position as of December 31, 2015, the Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Income (Loss), the Consolidated Statements of Stockholders Equity and the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows for the years ended December 31, 2015.
24090_18_ITEM15_P231_S0	The line item effects of these immaterial error corrections are detailed below.

24090_18_ITEM15_P249_S1	Settlement shall, in all events, occur prior to March 15th of the calendar year following the calendar year in which the RSUs become vested.
24090_18_ITEM15_P250_S0	(e) No Rights as a Stockholder.
24090_18_ITEM15_P250_S1	The Grantee shall not have any rights as a stockholder of the Company with respect to any shares of Common Stock corresponding to the RSUs granted hereby unless and until shares of Common Stock are issued to the Grantee in respect thereof.
24090_18_ITEM15_P251_S0	(f) Settlement of RSUs shall be contingent on the making appropriate arrangements for payment of amounts required to be withheld for federal, state and local income and wage taxes, or on the Company exercising its right to withhold Shares that are otherwise to be delivered on settlement of RSUs or to withhold amounts from other compensation payable to the Grantee so as to enable the Company to comply with its withholding obligations.
24090_18_ITEM15_P252_S0	Any cancellation or withholding of RSUs in connection with the Company s withholding obligations shall be deemed to be a taxable distribution of Shares corresponding to the cancelled or withheld RSUs and a repurchase of such Shares for federal income tax purposes at the time that occurs.
24090_18_ITEM15_P252_S1	The foregoing deemed distribution and repurchase of Shares need not be implemented, and a net issuance of Shares shall be permitted; provided, however, that the tax treatment shall be based on the deemed transaction described.
24090_18_ITEM15_P253_S0	In the event any dividends are paid to shareholders during the period following the Grant Date and up to the delivery of any Shares, the Grantee shall be entitled to a payment, at the same time the Shares are delivered to the Grantee, equal to the amount that would have been paid as dividends to the Grantee had the Grantee held the Shares during that period ( Dividend Equivalents ).
24090_18_ITEM15_P253_S1	In the event the underlying Shares are forfeited, the Dividend Equivalents shall also be forfeited.
24090_18_ITEM15_P253_S2	The Committee shall have the right to determine whether the Dividend Equivalents shall be paid in cash or in the form of a distribution of additional shares of Common Stock having the same value and to determine whether to deem such dividends to have been reinvested in shares at the time the dividends were paid.
24090_18_ITEM15_P254_S0	The effectiveness of this RSU Award granted hereunder is conditioned upon (i) the Grantee s having executed and delivered to the Company in connection with previous RSU grants a restrictive covenant, or (ii) the execution and delivery by the Grantee within 6 months from the date of this RSU Award of the restrictive covenant attached hereto as Exhibit A. If the Company does not receive the signed (whether electronically or otherwise) restrictive covenant within such six-month period, this RSU Award shall be terminable by the Company.

24090_18_ITEM15_P258_S1	As a consequence, the RSUs do not constitute property for purposes of Code Section 83.
24090_18_ITEM15_P258_S2	As a consequence, the Grantee will be taxable for federal income tax purposes on the value of the Shares distributed to the Grantee at the time the Shares are distributed, and not at the time the RSUs vest.

All requirements of the aforementioned exemption form Code Section 409A are intended to be met, and this Award Document shall be interpreted in a manner consistent with the Company s intent to satisfy such exemption requirements.

24090_18_ITEM15_P267_S0	The Participant acknowledges that the Company continually develops Confidential Information (as defined below), that the Participant may develop Confidential Information for the Company and that the Participant has had and will have access to and has become and will become aware of and informed of Confidential Information during the course of employment.
24090_18_ITEM15_P267_S1	For purposes of this Agreement, Confidential Information means any and all information of the Company that is not generally known by those with whom the Company competes or does business, or with whom the Company plans to compete or do business currently or during the course of the Participant s employment (as evidenced by the entry of discussions, a letter of intent, or definitive agreement for any such purpose), one or more activities which constitute the business, and any and all information, publicly known in whole or in part or not, which, if disclosed by the Company would assist in competition against them.

24090_18_ITEM15_P267_S5	The Participant understands that the Participant s obligations under this Section 1 shall continue to apply after the termination of the Participant s employment, regardless of the reason for such termination.
24090_18_ITEM15_P267_S6	The confidentiality obligation under this Section 1 shall not apply to information which (i) is generally known or readily available to the public at the time of disclosure, (ii) becomes generally known through no act on the part of the Participant in breach of this Agreement or any other person known to the Participant to have an obligation of confidentiality to the Company with respect to such information, (iii) is disclosed in furtherance of the Participant s duties as an employee of the Company, or (iv) restricts or prohibits the Participant from initiating communications directly with, responding to any inquiries from, providing testimony before, providing Confidential Information to, reporting possible violations of law or regulation to, or from filing a claim or assisting with an investigation directly with a self-regulatory authority or a government agency, or from making other disclosures that are protected under the whistleblower provisions of state or federal law or regulation.
24090_18_ITEM15_P268_S0	Pursuant to 18 USC 1833(b) (the Defend Trade Secrets Act of 2016), the Participant acknowledges that an individual may not be held liable under any criminal or civil federal or state trade secret law for disclosure of a trade secret: (i) made in confidence to a government official, either directly or indirectly, or to an attorney, solely for the purpose of reporting or investigating a suspected violation of law or (ii) in a complaint or other document filed in a lawsuit or other proceeding, if such filing is made under seal.
24090_18_ITEM15_P268_S1	Additionally, an individual suing an entity for retaliation based on the reporting of a suspected violation of law may disclose a trade secret to his or her attorney and use the trade secret information in the court proceeding, so long as any document containing the trade secret is filed under seal and the individual does not disclose the trade secret except pursuant to court order.
24090_18_ITEM15_P268_S2	Nothing in this Agreement is intended to conflict with 18 USC 1833(b) or create liability for disclosures of trade secrets that are expressly allowed by 18 USC 1833(b).
